forlængelse -n, -r, -rne 延长，延续

entry.title: 算法和计算复杂度 12 PCP-based Inapproximability
entry.content:
For MAXCLIQUEMAXCLIQUEMAXCLIQUE problem. A constant factor polynomial-time approximation algorithm doesn’t exist unless NP∈DTIME(2(log⁡n)O(1))NP\in DTIME(2^{(\log n)^{O(1)}})NP∈DTIME(2(logn)O(1)), based on the theorem that NP⊆PCP((log⁡n)O(1),(log⁡n)O(1))NP\subseteq PCP((\log n)^{O(1)},(\log n)^{O(1)})NP⊆PCP((logn)O(1),(logn)O(1)).

Use a different approach the final PCPPCPPCP theorem implies that a constant factor polynomial-time approximation algorithm for MAXE3SATMAXE3SATMAXE3SAT doesn’t exist unless P=NPP=NPP=NP.

Optimization is hard ⇒\Rarr⇒ A corresponding gap version of decision problem is hard.

📖Definition 53. An NPNPNP-optimization problem Π\PiΠ is given by a polynomial ppp, a language L∈PL\in PL∈P, a polynomial-time computable function valvalval called objective function, and a choice of being either a maximization problem or a minimization problem. For a given xxx, define the set F(x)F(x)F(x) of feasible solution by

F(x)=\{y:|y|\le p(|x|)\and\langle x,y\rangle\in L\}.

Assume that F(x)≠∅F(x)\neq\emptyF(x)=∅ for any xxx. The function valvalval takes as input xxx and y∈F(x)y\in F(x)y∈F(x) and assigns a value val(x,y)≥0val(x,y)\ge0val(x,y)≥0 to the feasible solution yyy to instance xxx.

Denote valx(y)val_x(y)valx​(y) for val(x,y)val(x,y)val(x,y).

  • If Π\PiΠ is a maximization problem, OPT(x)=max⁡y∈F(x)valx(y)OPT(x)=\max_{y\in F(x)}val_x(y)OPT(x)=maxy∈F(x)​valx​(y).
  • If Π\PiΠ is a minimization problem, OPT(x)=miny∈F(x)valx(y)OPT(x)=min_{y\in F(x)}val_x(y)OPT(x)=miny∈F(x)​valx​(y).

A feasible solution y∈F(x)y\in F(x)y∈F(x) s.t. valx(y)=OPT(x)val_x(y)=OPT(x)valx​(y)=OPT(x) is called an optimal solution for xxx.

“Gap-version” reduction: The corresponding decision problem is that of asking whether OPT(x)≥KOPT(x)\ge KOPT(x)≥K in case of a maximization problem or whether OPT(x)≤KOPT(x)\le KOPT(x)≤K in case of a minimization problem.

When this is NPNPNP-hard, it follows that there is no polynomial-time algorithm that on input xxx computes an optimal solution for xxx unless P=NPP=NPP=NP.

📖Definition 54. Let Π\PiΠ be an NPNPNP-optimization problem and let ρ:N→R+\rho:\N\to\R_+ρ:N→R+​ be a function. A ρ\rhoρ-approximation algorithm AAA is an algorithm that on input xxx gives as output y∈F(x)y\in F(x)y∈F(x) s.t. valx(y)≥ρ(∣x∣)OPT(x)val_x(y)\ge\rho(|x|)OPT(x)valx​(y)≥ρ(∣x∣)OPT(x) in case of a maximization problem Π\PiΠ or such that valx(y)≤ρ(x)OPT(x)val_x(y)\le\rho(x)OPT(x)valx​(y)≤ρ(x)OPT(x) in case of a minimization problem Π\PiΠ.

Let Π\PiΠ be an NPNPNP-maximization problem and let a,b:N→R+a,b:\N\to\R_+a,b:N→R+​ be functions s.t. 0<a(n)<b(n)0\lt a(n)\lt b(n)0<a(n)<b(n) for all nnn. Then define the following promise decision problem.

(a,b)−GAP−Π(a,b)-GAP-\Pi(a,b)−GAP−Π:

  • Input: xxx s.t. either OPT(x)≤a(∣x∣)OPT(x)\le a(|x|)OPT(x)≤a(∣x∣) or OPT(x)≥b(∣x∣)OPT(x)\ge b(|x|)OPT(x)≥b(∣x∣).
  • Question: Is OPT(x)≥b(∣x∣)OPT(x)\ge b(|x|)OPT(x)≥b(∣x∣).

📖Definition 55. We say that (a,b)−GAP−Π(a,b)-GAP-\Pi(a,b)−GAP−Π is NPNPNP-hard if there is a polynomial-time computable function fff s.t.

  1. If x∈SATx\in SATx∈SAT then f(x)f(x)f(x) is an instance of Π\PiΠ and OPT(f(x))≥b(∣f(x)∣)OPT(f(x))\ge b(|f(x)|)OPT(f(x))≥b(∣f(x)∣).
  2. If x∉SATx\not\in SATx∈SAT then f(x)f(x)f(x) is an instance of Π\PiΠ and OPT(f(x))≤a(f(∣x∣))OPT(f(x))\le a(f(|x|))OPT(f(x))≤a(f(∣x∣)).

🤔Proposition 19. Suppose that (a,b)−GAP−Π(a,b)-GAP-\Pi(a,b)−GAP−Π is NPNPNP-hard. Then there is no polynomial-time ρ\rhoρ-approximation for Π\PiΠ s.t. ρ(n)>a(n)b(n)\rho(n)\gt\frac{a(n)}{b(n)}ρ(n)>b(n)a(n)​ unless P=NPP=NPP=NP.

The FGLSS reduction

这真的是人能想出来的规约么

Let L∈PCPc,s(r(n),q(n))L\in PCP_{c,s}(r(n),q(n))L∈PCPc,s​(r(n),q(n)) and let VVV be a corresponding PCPPCPPCP verifier.

WLOG, VVV makes q(n)q(n)q(n) queries to the proof on input xxx of length nnn.

For an input xxx, we define a graph G(x)G(x)G(x) from VVV calledd the FGLSSFGLSSFGLSS graph. The set of vertices G(x)G(x)G(x) are all pairs (y,z)∈{0,1}r(n)×{0,1}q(n)(y,z)\in\{0,1\}^{r(n)}\times\{0,1\}^{q(n)}(y,z)∈{0,1}r(n)×{0,1}q(n).

A pair of distinct vertices (y1,z1)(y_1,z_1)(y1​,z1​) and (y2,z2)(y_2,z_2)(y2​,z2​) are connected by an edge iff there exist a proof π\piπ s.t. the following holds:

  1. Using y1y_1y1​ in place of the random bits Vπ(x)V^\pi(x)Vπ(x) accepts and the positions read from the proof π\piπ contain exactly the contents of z1z_1z1​.
  2. Using y2y_2y2​ in place of the random bits Vπ(x)V^\pi(x)Vπ(x) accepts and the positions read from the proof π\piπ contain exactly the contents of z2z_2z2​.

👀For a fixed input xxx, the positions read from the proof are determined just by the string y∈{0,1}r(n)y\in\{0,1\}^{r(n)}y∈{0,1}r(n) of random bits.

Thus in the graph G(x)G(x)G(x) there are no edges between (y,z1)(y,z_1)(y,z1​) and (y,z2)(y,z_2)(y,z2​) for z1≠z2z_1\neq z_2z1​=z2​.

A clique in G(x)G(x)G(x) must consist of vertices (y1,z1),⋯ ,(yk,zk)(y_1,z_1),\cdots,(y_k,z_k)(y1​,z1​),⋯,(yk​,zk​) for which all the strings y1,⋯ ,yky_1,\cdots,y_ky1​,⋯,yk​ are distinct.

Now define MAXCLIQUEMAXCLIQUEMAXCLIQUE

Clique，中文翻译为“完全子图”。最大完全子图就是要找包含点数最多的完全子图。这个问题是 NP-complete 的。

  • Instance: A graph GGG.
  • Output: Clique in GGG of maximum size.

🤔Lemma 20. Let VVV be a PCPPCPPCP verifier using r(n)r(n)r(n) random bits and querying q(n)q(n)q(n) symbols from a proof π∈{0,1}∗\pi\in\{0,1\}^*π∈{0,1}∗. For an input xxx we have

OPT(G(x))=2r(n)max⁡πPr⁡[Vπ(x)=yes].OPT(G(x))=2^{r(n)}\max_\pi\Pr[V^\pi(x)=yes].OPT(G(x))=2r(n)πmax​Pr[Vπ(x)=yes].

🤔Corollary 13. Let L∈PCPc,s(r(n),q(n))L\in PCP_{c,s}(r(n),q(n))L∈PCPc,s​(r(n),q(n)) and let VVV be a corresponding PCP verifier. Then using time 2O(r(n)+q(n))nO(1)2^{O(r(n)+q(n))}n^{O(1)}2O(r(n)+q(n))nO(1) on input xxx of length nnn a graph G(x)G(x)G(x) with 2r(n)+q(n)2^{r(n)+q(n)}2r(n)+q(n) vertices can be computed s.t.

  • If x∈Lx\in Lx∈L then OPT(G(x))≥c2r(n)OPT(G(x))\ge c2^{r(n)}OPT(G(x))≥c2r(n).
  • If x∉Lx\not\in Lx∈L then OPT(G(x))≤s2r(n)OPT(G(x))\le s2^{r(n)}OPT(G(x))≤s2r(n).

Since NP∈PCP(O(log⁡n),O(1))NP\in PCP(O(\log n),O(1))NP∈PCP(O(logn),O(1)), there is a δ>0\delta\gt0δ>0 s.t. (12δn,δn)−GAP−MAXCLIQUE(\frac{1}{2}\delta n,\delta n)-GAP-MAXCLIQUE(21​δn,δn)−GAP−MAXCLIQUE that for MAXCLIQUEMAXCLIQUEMAXCLIQUE there is no (12+ϵ)(\frac{1}{2}+\epsilon)(21​+ϵ)-approximation algorithm, for any ϵ>0\epsilon\gt0ϵ>0, unless P=NPP=NPP=NP.

🎯Theorem 54. For any constant ρ>0\rho\gt0ρ>0, there is no polynomial time ρ\rhoρ-approximation algorithm for MAXCLIQUEMAXCLIQUEMAXCLIQUE unless P=NPP=NPP=NP.

Actually, it is possible to do success amplification in a randomness efficient manner using random walks on expander graphs. This leads to NP⊆PCP1,1/n(O(log⁡n),O(log⁡n))NP\subseteq PCP_{1,1/n}(O(\log n),O(\log n))NP⊆PCP1,1/n​(O(logn),O(logn)) which leads to a stronger result.

🎯Theorem 55. There exist a constant ϵ>0\epsilon\gt0ϵ>0 s.t. there is no 1nϵ\frac{1}{n^\epsilon}nϵ1​-approximation algorithm for MAXCLIQUEMAXCLIQUEMAXCLIQUE unless P=NPP=NPP=NP.

By using a weaker version of theorem 52 that computing FGLSSFGLSSFGLSS takes 2(log⁡n)O(1)2^{(\log n)^{O(1)}}2(logn)O(1) time, we have a weaker version of theorem 54.

🎯Theorem 56 (weaker than 54). For any constant ρ>0\rho\gt0ρ>0, there is no ρ\rhoρ-approximation algorithm for MAXCLIQUEMAXCLIQUEMAXCLIQUE running in time 2(log⁡n)O(1)2^{(\log n)^{O(1)}}2(logn)O(1) unless NP≠⊆DTIME(2(log⁡n)O(1))NP\neq\subseteq DTIME(2^{(\log n)^{O(1)}})NP=⊆DTIME(2(logn)O(1)).

🎯Theorem 57. For any constant ϵ>0\epsilon\gt0ϵ>0 there is no polynomial time 1n1−ϵ\frac{1}{n^{1-\epsilon}}n1−ϵ1​-approximation algorithm for MAXCLIQUEMAXCLIQUEMAXCLIQUE unless P=NPP=NPP=NP.

Constraint Satisfaction Problem

📖Definition 56. A constraint satisfaction problem (CSP) is given by a finite set Σ\SigmaΣ, an integer qqq and a list of functions Φ=(φ1,φ2,⋯ ,φm)\Phi=(\varphi_1,\varphi_2,\cdots,\varphi_m)Φ=(φ1​,φ2​,⋯,φm​) where φi\varphi_iφi​ are called constraints, qqq the arity, and Σ\SigmaΣ the alphabet. An input x∈Σnx\in\Sigma^nx∈Σn satisfies the constraint φi\varphi_iφi​ if φi(x)=1\varphi_i(x)=1φi​(x)=1. Define

val(Φ)=1mmax⁡x∣{i∈{1,⋯ ,m}∣φi(x)=1}∣.val(\Phi)=\frac{1}{m}\max_x|\{i\in\{1,\cdots,m\}|\varphi_i(x)=1\}|.val(Φ)=m1​xmax​∣{i∈{1,⋯,m}∣φi​(x)=1}∣.

Let MAXqCSPΣMAX_qCSP_\SigmaMAXq​CSPΣ​ be the optimization problem where the input is any CSP with qqq-ary constraints over an alphabet Σ\SigmaΣ.

When Σ={0,1}\Sigma=\{0,1\}Σ={0,1}, we called it MAXqCSPMAX_qCSPMAXq​CSP.

MAXE3SATMAXE3SATMAXE3SAT problem can be phrased as CSPCSPCSP with 3-ary constraint over the binary alphabet.

MAXE3SATMAXE3SATMAXE3SAT:

  • Instance: CNF formula φ\varphiφ where each clause contains 3 distinct variables.
  • Output: Assignment xxx maximizing the fraction of satisfied clauses.

The existence of an ϵ<1\epsilon\lt1ϵ<1 such that (ϵ,1)−GAP−MAXE3SAT(\epsilon,1)-GAP-MAXE3SAT(ϵ,1)−GAP−MAXE3SAT is NPNPNP-hard.

🎯Theorem 58. For fixed s<cs\lt cs<c we have that NP⊆PCPc,sΣ(O(log⁡n),q)NP\subseteq PCP_{c,s}^\Sigma(O(\log n),q)NP⊆PCPc,sΣ​(O(logn),q) iff (s,c)−GAP−MAXqCSPΣ(s,c)-GAP-MAX_qCSP_\Sigma(s,c)−GAP−MAXq​CSPΣ​ is NPNPNP-hard.

🎯Theorem 59. There exist ϵ<1\epsilon\lt1ϵ<1 s.t. (ϵ,1)−GAP−MAXE3SAT(\epsilon,1)-GAP-MAXE3SAT(ϵ,1)−GAP−MAXE3SAT is NPNPNP-hard.

entry.title: 算法和计算复杂度 13 Random Access Machine
entry.content:
More precise model

Problem of integer multiplication.

Registers can contain arbitrary integers. Consider repeated squaring to number 222. After just nnn multiplications, the resulting number is 22n2^{2^n}22n, a doubly exponential large number in nnn. This requires exponential number of bits.

A RAM has an infinite sequence of registers each able to contain an arbitrary non-negative integer.

  • Machine is controlled by a program consisting of a list of instructions.
  • Registers can be added or subtracted.
  • Contents of a register can be stored or retrieved in a second register by means of indirect addressing using a third register.
  • Execution can be controlled by conditional jumps in the list of instructions.

The cost for using a register containing the integer nnn is given by a cost function ℓ(n)\ell(n)ℓ(n).

  • Having ℓ(n)=1\ell(n)=1ℓ(n)=1 gives the unit-cost RAM
  • Having ℓ(n)=⌈log⁡2(n+1)⌉\ell(n)=\lceil\log_2(n+1)\rceilℓ(n)=⌈log2​(n+1)⌉ gives the logarithmic-cost RAM.

Don’t include multiplication as a basic operation in this model.

The RAM and the Turing machine models of computation can simulate each other with only a logarithmic factor.

The word RAM model refines the integer RAM by bounding the magnitude of the numbers that can be stored in a single register, and having unit cost operations on these.

This is formally done by introducing a parameter www, called the word-size, and having each register can store an element of {0,1}w\{0,1\}^w{0,1}w.

The word size www will increase with the length of the input nnn, and in particular we have w=Ω(log⁡n)w=\Omega(\log n)w=Ω(logn) to be able to perform indirectly random access to the entire input.

The basic set of instructions, gives restricted word RAM, consists of addition, subtraction, left and right shifts, and bit-wise AND, OR, NOT.

A common extension is to include integer multiplication as a unit cost operation.

Another extension is exclude integer multiplication but allow all functions computable by AC0AC^0AC0 circuits of polynomial size in www, thus giving the AC0AC^0AC0 word RAM.

The typical setting of the word size, known as the trans-dichotomous setting, is to have w=Θ(log⁡n)w=\Theta(\log n)w=Θ(logn).

Some Algorithms requires a larger word size.

A notable example is the task of sorting nnn integers. When w=Ω(log⁡2+ϵn)w=\Omega(\log^{2+\epsilon}n)w=Ω(log2+ϵn) a randomized algorithm using expected time O(n)O(n)O(n) exists.

The best known algorithm that works for all word sizes, uses O(nlog⁡log⁡n)O(n\sqrt{\log\log n})O(nloglogn​) time.

entry.title: Fair AI/ML 5 PROP in Non-Centroid Clustering
entry.content:
Read the paper Proportional Fairness in Non-Centroid Clustering by Caragiannis et al.

This paper was accepted in NeurIPS 2024!

Introduction

nnn points, kkk clusters C=(C1,⋯ ,Ck)C=(C_1,\cdots,C_k)C=(C1​,⋯,Ck​), distance metric ddd.

kkk-means objective: ∑i=1k1∣Ci∣⋅∑x,y∈Cid(x,y)2\sum_{i=1}^k\frac{1}{|C_i|}\cdot\sum_{x,y\in C_i}d(x,y)^2∑i=1k​∣Ci​∣1​⋅∑x,y∈Ci​​d(x,y)2.

Scenario in which there are no cluster centers.

Question:

  1. Can we obtain PROP guarantee for non-centroid clustering?
  2. Do the algorithms for centroid clustering also work for non-centroid one?
  3. Can we audit the PROP of a given algorithm?

Contribution

Each agent iii has a loss function ℓi\ell_iℓi​, the loss under clustering CCC is ℓi(C(i))\ell_i(C(i))ℓi​(C(i)). C(i)C(i)C(i) denotes the cluster containing her.

  • ℓi\ell_iℓi​ can be arbitrary
  • ℓi\ell_iℓi​ can be distance

PROP fairness guarantee:

  1. the core
  2. and its relaxation, fully justified representation FJR.

Summary of results

Loss functionsCore UBCore LBFJR
Arbitrary∞\infty∞∞\infty∞111
AverageO(n/k)O(n/k)O(n/k) polytime1.31.31.3111 (444 in polytime)
Maximum222 polytime111111 (222 in polytime)

FJR as a relaxation of the core. This paper propose GreedyCohesiveClustering, which is an adaptation of Greedy Cohesive Rule from social choice theory.

Related Work

PROP by Chen et al.

PROP revisit by Micha and Shah

FJR in centroid clustering by Aziz et al.

Model

[t]={1,⋯ ,t}[t]=\{1,\cdots,t\}[t]={1,⋯,t} for t∈Nt\in\Nt∈N. Given a set NNN of nnn agents, and the desired number of clusters kkk.

Each agent i∈Ni\in Ni∈N has an associated loss function ℓi:2N╲2N╲i→R≥0\ell_i:2^N\diagdown2^{N\diagdown i}\to\R_{\ge0}ℓi​:2N╲2N╲i→R≥0​, where ℓi(S)\ell_i(S)ℓi​(S) is the cost to agent iii for being part of group SSS. A kkk-clustering C=(C1,⋯ ,Ck)C=(C_1,\cdots,C_k)C=(C1​,⋯,Ck​) is a partition of NNN into kkk clusters, where Ct∩Ct′=∅C_t\cap C_{t'}=\emptyCt​∩Ct′​=∅ for t≠t′t\neq t't=t′ and ∪t=1kCt=N\cup_{t=1}^kC_t=N∪t=1k​Ct​=N. For simplicity, C(i)C(i)C(i) is the cluster containing iii.

The loss of iii is ℓi(C(i))\ell_i(C(i))ℓi​(C(i)).

Loss function

  • A distance metric over NNN is given by d:N×N→R≥0d:N\times N\to\R_{\ge0}d:N×N→R≥0​, which satisfies normality, symmetry and triangle inequality.
  • Arbitrary losses. The loss ℓi(S)\ell_i(S)ℓi​(S) is arbitrary non-negative number for each agent i∈Ni\in Ni∈N and cluster S∋iS\ni iS∋i.
  • Average loss. Given a distance metric ddd over NNN, ℓi(S)=1∣S∣∑j∈Sd(i,j)\ell_i(S)=\frac{1}{|S|}\sum_{j\in S}d(i,j)ℓi​(S)=∣S∣1​∑j∈S​d(i,j) for each agent i∈Ni\in Ni∈N and cluster S∋iS\ni iS∋i. Agent iii prefers the agents in her cluster to be close to her on average.
  • Maximum loss. Given a distance metric ddd, ℓi(S)=max⁡j∈Sd(i,j)\ell_i(S)=\max_{j\in S}d(i,j)ℓi​(S)=maxj∈S​d(i,j). Agent iii prefers that no agent in her cluster to be too far from her.

Core

If no group of agents S⊆NS\subseteq NS⊆N can choose another outcome that

  1. They are entitled to choose based on their proportion of the whole population ∣S∣/∣N∣|S|/|N|∣S∣/∣N∣
  2. Every member of group SSS is happier

📖Definition 1 (α\alphaα-Core). For α≥1\alpha\ge1α≥1, a kkk-clustering C=(C1,⋯ ,Ck)C=(C_1,\cdots,C_k)C=(C1​,⋯,Ck​) is said to be in the α\alphaα-core if there is no group of agents S⊆NS\subseteq NS⊆N with ∣S∣≥n/k|S|\ge n/k∣S∣≥n/k s.t. α⋅ℓi(S)<ℓi(C(i))\alpha\cdot\ell_i(S)\lt\ell_i(C(i))α⋅ℓi​(S)<ℓi​(C(i)) for all i∈Si\in Si∈S. 111-core is the core.

If a group SSS exists that becomes a violation of the α\alphaα-core guarantee, we say that it deviates and refer to it as the deviating coalition.

🎯Theorem 1. For arbitrary losses, there exists an instance in which no α\alphaα-core clustering for any finite α\alphaα.

🎯Theorem 2. For the average loss, there exists an instance in which no α\alphaα-core clustering exists an instance in which no α\alphaα-core clustering exists for α<1+32≈1.366\alpha\lt\frac{1+\sqrt3}{2}\approx1.366α<21+3​​≈1.366.

❓Open problem 1: For the maximum loss, does there always exist a clustering in the core?

❓Open problem 2: For the average loss, does there always exist a clustering in the α\alphaα-core for some constant α\alphaα?

GreedyCohesiveClustering Algorithm

It uses a subroutine A\mathcal AA, in which given a subset of agents N′⊆NN'\subseteq NN′⊆N, metric ddd, and threshold τ\tauτ, finds a cohesive cluster SSS.

The threshold τ\tauτ indicate the smallest size at which a group of agents deserve to form a cluster.

A\mathcal AA is SmallestAgentBall. It finds the smallest ball centered at agent that captures at least τ\tauτ agents, and returns a set of τ\tauτ agents from this ball.

  • Natural choice: τ=⌈n/k⌉\tau=\lceil n/k\rceilτ=⌈n/k⌉

So GreedyCohesiveClustering with SmallestAgentBall iteratively finds the smallest agent-centered ball containing ⌈n/k⌉\lceil n/k\rceil⌈n/k⌉ agents and removes ⌈n/k⌉\lceil n/k\rceil⌈n/k⌉ in that ball, until fewer than ⌈n/k⌉\lceil n/k\rceil⌈n/k⌉ agents remain, at which point all remaining agents are put into one cluster and any remaining clusters are left empty.

Pseudo code for GreedyCohesiveClustering

Input: N,d,kN,d,kN,d,k

Output: kkk-clustering CCC

  1. N′←NN'\gets NN′←N // remaining set of agents
  2. j←1j\gets 1j←1 // current cluster member
  3. while N′≠∅N'\neq\emptyN′=∅ do
    • Cj←A(N′,d,⌈n/k⌉)C_j\gets\mathcal A(N',d,\lceil n/k\rceil)Cj​←A(N′,d,⌈n/k⌉) // find and remove the next cohesive cluster
    • N′←N′╲CjN'\gets N'\diagdown C_jN′←N′╲Cj​
    • j←j+1j\gets j+1j←j+1
  4. Cj,Cj+1,⋯ ,Ck←∅C_j,C_{j+1},\cdots,C_k\gets\emptyCj​,Cj+1​,⋯,Ck​←∅
  5. return C=(C1,⋯ ,Ck)C=(C_1,\cdots,C_k)C=(C1​,⋯,Ck​)

Pseudo code for SmallestAgentBall

Input: Subset of agent N′⊆N,d,τN'\subseteq N,d,\tauN′⊆N,d,τ

Output: a cluster SSS

  1. if ∣N′∣≤τ|N'|\le\tau∣N′∣≤τ then return S←N′S\gets N'S←N′
  2. if i∈N′i\in N'i∈N′ do
    • ℓi←τ\ell_i\gets\tauℓi​←τ-th closest agent in N′N'N′ to agent iii // arbitrarily broke the tie
    • ri←d(i,ℓi)r_i\gets d(i,\ell_i)ri​←d(i,ℓi​) // smallest ball centered at agent iii capturing at least τ\tauτ agents
  3. i∗←arg⁡min⁡i∈N′rii^*\gets\arg\min_{i\in N'}r_ii∗←argmini∈N′​ri​
  4. return S←S\getsS← the set of τ\tauτ closest agents in N′N'N′ to agent i∗i^*i∗

Actually the GreedyCohesiveClustering is an adaptation of Greedy Capture by Chen et al. There are two key difference:

  1. Growing balls centered at the agents instead of all feasible candidate centers.
  2. Stop a ball as soon as it captures ⌈n/k⌉\lceil n/k\rceil⌈n/k⌉ agents. While in GC, it continues.

🎯Theorem 3. For the average (resp. maximum) loss, the Greedy Capture algorithm is guaranteed to return a clustering in the (2⌈n/k⌉−3)(2\lceil n/k\rceil -3)(2⌈n/k⌉−3)-core (resp. 222-core) in O(kn)O(kn)O(kn) time complexity, and the bounds are tight.

Fully Justified Representation

Peters et al. introduced FJR as a relaxation of the core in the context of approval-based committee selection.

📖 Definition 2 (α\alphaα-FJR). For α≥1\alpha\ge1α≥1, a kkk-clustering CCC satisfies α\alphaα-FJR if there is no group of agents S⊆NS\subseteq NS⊆N with ∣S∣≥n/k|S|\ge n/k∣S∣≥n/k s.t. α⋅ℓi(S)<min⁡j∈Sℓj(C(j))\alpha\cdot\ell_i(S)\lt\min_{j\in S}\ell_j(C(j))α⋅ℓi​(S)<minj∈S​ℓj​(C(j)) for each i∈Si\in Si∈S, i.e., if α⋅max⁡i∈Sℓi(S)<min⁡j∈Sℓj(C(j))\alpha\cdot\max_{i\in S}\ell_i(S)\lt\min_{j\in S}\ell_j(C(j))α⋅maxi∈S​ℓi​(S)<minj∈S​ℓj​(C(j)). We refer to 111-FJR as FJR.

🤔Proposition 1. For α≥1\alpha\ge1α≥1, α\alphaα-core implies α\alphaα-FJR for arbitrary loss functions.

Trivially, ℓi(C(i))≥min⁡j∈Sℓj(C(j))\ell_i(C(i))\ge\min_{j\in S}\ell_j(C(j))ℓi​(C(i))≥minj∈S​ℓj​(C(j)).

Arbitrary Loss Functions

FJR clustering is guaranteed to exist even for arbitrary losses.

📖Definition 3 (most cohesive cluster). Given a set of agents NNN and a threshold τ\tauτ, the MostChesiveCluster problem asks to find a cluster S⊆NS\subseteq NS⊆N of size at least τ\tauτ s.t. the maximum loss of any i∈Si\in Si∈S for SSS is minimized, i.e., find arg⁡min⁡S⊆N′:∣S∣≥τmax⁡i∈Sℓi(S)\arg\min_{S\subseteq N':|S|\ge\tau}\max_{i\in S}\ell_i(S)argminS⊆N′:∣S∣≥τ​maxi∈S​ℓi​(S).

For λ≥1\lambda\ge1λ≥1, a λ\lambdaλ-approximate solution SSS satisfies λ⋅max⁡i∈Sℓi(S)≤max⁡i∈S′λi(S′)\lambda\cdot\max_{i\in S}\ell_i(S)\le\max_{i\in S'}\lambda_i(S')λ⋅maxi∈S​ℓi​(S)≤maxi∈S′​λi​(S′) for all S′⊆NS'\subseteq NS′⊆N with ∣S′∣≥τ|S'|\ge\tau∣S′∣≥τ, and a λ\lambdaλ-approx algorithm returns a λ\lambdaλ-approx solution on every instance.

If we plug in A\mathcal AA to the MostCohesiveCluster problem into GreedyCohesiveClustering algorithm yields λ\lambdaλ-FJR clustering.

🎯Theorem 4. For arbitrary losses, α≥1\alpha\ge1α≥1, and an α\alphaα-approximation algorithm A\mathcal AA for the MostCohesiveCluster problem, GreeedyCohesiveClustering is guaranteed to return a α\alphaα-FJR clustering. Hence, FJR is guaranteed to exist.

Proof omitted.

Average and Maximum Loss Functions

Let A∗\mathcal A^*A∗ be an exact ALG for the MostCohesiveCluster problem for the average loss.

It may run not in polynomial time. It can be used to detect whether a given undirected graph admits a clique of at least a given size (NP-Complete).

🤔Lemma 1. For the average (resp. maximum) loss, SmallestAgentBall is a 444-approximation (resp. 222-approximation) algorithm for the MostCohesiveCluster problem, and this is tight.

🤔Corollary 1. The Greedy Capture algorithm is guaranteed to return a clustering that is 444-FJR (resp. 222-FJR) for the average (resp. maximum) loss.

❓Open problem 3: For the average or maximum loss, what is the smallest α\alphaα for which an α\alphaα-FJR clustering can be computed in polynomial time, assuming P≠NPP\neq NPP=NP?

❓Open problem 4: What is the smallest α\alphaα s.t. there always exists a clustering that is simultaneously α\alphaα-FJR for both the average loss and the maximum loss?

Auditing FJR

Ideas used to find an approx FJR can also be used to audit the FJR approx of any given clustering.

📖Definition 4 (λ\lambdaλ-approx FJR auditing). A\mathcal AA is a λ\lambdaλ-approx FJR auditing algorithm, if given any clustering CCC, it returns θ\thetaθ s.t. the exact FJR approx of CCC is in [θ,λ⋅θ][\theta,\lambda\cdot\theta][θ,λ⋅θ].

🎯Theorem 5. For λ≥1\lambda\ge1λ≥1, if A\mathcal AA is a λ\lambdaλ-approx algorithm to the MostCohesiveCluster problem, then AuditFJR(A)(\mathcal A)(A) is a λ\lambdaλ-approx FJR auditing algorithm. Given lemma 1, it follows that for the average (resp. maximum) loss, AuditFJR(SmallestAgentBall) is an efficient 444-approx (resp. 222-approx) FJR auditing algorithm.

❓Open problem 5: Does there exist a polynomial time, α\alphaα-approx core auditing algorithm for some constant α\alphaα?

🎯Theorem 6. Assuming P≠NPP\neq NPP=NP, there does not exist a polynomial-time λ\lambdaλ-approx FJR auditing algorithm for the maximum loss, for any λ<2\lambda\lt2λ<2,

Experiments

Omitted

Discussion

Introduction to Proportional Fairness in Non-Centroid Clustering: This paper initiates the study of proportional fairness in non-centroid clustering and presents several open questions for further exploration.

Key Open Questions:

  • Achieving a better approximation than O(n/k)O(n/k)O(n/k) for the core concerning average loss.
  • Determining if the core is always non-empty for maximum loss.

Core Non-Emptiness Results:

  • Proven that the core is always non-empty for maximum loss in 1-dimensional metric spaces (Appendix C.1).
  • For average loss, however, the core remains empty even on the line (Appendix C.2).

Differences Between Clustering Settings:

  • Highlights significant distinctions between centroid and non-centroid clustering.

Future Directions:

  • Investigate proportional fairness guarantees when an agent’s loss depends on both their cluster center and other agents in their cluster.
  • Explore the possibility of intrinsically choosing the number of clusters kkk, which currently requires being fixed in advance for proportional fairness.

Compatibility with Classical Algorithms:

  • While traditional algorithms like kkk-means and kkk-centers may be incompatible with the core and FJR (Appendix E), studying conditions under which they might align with fairness criteria or can be efficiently computed is an interesting avenue.
entry.summary: Read the paper Proportional Fairness in Non-Centroid

entry.title: 丹麦语 DU 3.3 9 Jobsøgning
entry.content:
Edison søger job

krævende 苛求的

et par måneder 几个月

indtil 直到

vikariat -et, -er, -erne 临时职位

kvalifikation -en, -er, -erne 资格

rutinepræget -, …prægede 固定程序的，无脑的

utilfredsstillende 令人不满意的

afvekslende adv 交互，交替

udfordrende 有挑战的

allerførst -, -e 首先，第一

personlighed -en, -er, -erne 个性，性格

kompetence -n, -r, -rne 能力，权力，专长

overfladisk -, -e 皮毛的，浅层次的，表面的

nysgerrig -t, -e 好奇的

indadvendt -, - 内向的

udadvendt -, - 外向的

målrettet -, målrettede 坚定的，果断的

resultatorienteret 以结果为导向的

holdspiller -en, -e, -ne 团队成员

mene 认为，意思是

  • NOGEN mener at + SÆTNING
  • NOGEN mener NOGET om NOGEN/NOGET

i hvert fald 无论如何

tankevækkende -, - 引人深思的，发人深省的

jobjagt 找工作 = jobsøgning

Adjektiver afledt af verber

来自动词的形容词，和德语的动词第一分词、第二分词差不多

现在分词作为形容词

Man kan danne adjektiver af en række verber og således skifte ordklasse. Man kan danne adjektiver af verber ved at tilføje endelsen - ende til verbets rod ( f.eks. smil-ende). Denne form kaldes “præsens participium”.

现在分词 aka 第一分词

VerbumRodAdjektiv
smilersmilsmilende
stråler 发光strålstrålende 非常好的，辉煌的
leverlevlevende 活的
irritererirriterirriterende
dominererdominerdominerende 主宰的

⚠️Bemærk: Præsens participium betegner noget, som sker nu.

  • F.eks.: Kogende vand = vand, der koger nu. 正在沸腾的水

过去分词作为形容词

Man kan også danne adjektiver af verber ved at tilføje -(e)t til verbets rod ( f.eks. udlær -t ). Denne form kaldes “perfektum participium”.

过去分词 aka 第二分词

VerbumRodAdjektiv
uddanneruddanuddannet 受过教育的
malermalmalet
kogerkogkogt
fyrerfyrfyret 发射过的；被解雇的
stegerstegstegt 烤过的
brugerbrugbrugt 使用过的
betalerbetalbetalt 支付过的

⚠️Bemærk: Perfektum participium betegner noget, som allerede er sket.

  • F.eks. : Kogt vand = vand, der har kogt (måske er det koldt igen) 已经沸腾过的水

⚠️Bemærk: Vi bruger tit forstavelserne: “vel”, “u” om noget godt/dårligt, f.eks.: veluddannet, velkvalificeret, uengageret, uinspireret, umotiveret.

Passiv

复习被动态

情态动词 + 动词-s不定式现在时过去式现在完成时
at fyreskal fyresat blive fyretbliver fyretblev fyreter blevet fyret
at forfremmeskal forfremmesat blive forfremmetbliver forfremmetblev forfremmeter blevet forfremmet
at indkaldeskal indkaldesat blive indkaldtbliver indkaldtblev indkaldter blevet indkaldt
at opsigeskal opsigesat blive opsigtbliver opsigtblev opsigter blevet opsigt
  1. 在情态动词后：动词使用 s-form
  2. 其他情况下，使用助动词 blive + 动词过去分词

entry.title: 算法和计算复杂度 11 Probabilistic Checkable Proofs
entry.content:
Proof systems where a polynomial-time probabilistic verifier can spot-check a given written proof by inspecting a few randomly selected symbols of the proof. Cost: Introducing some error.

📖Definition 48 (PCP verifier). A (non-adaptive) PCP verifier VVV is a polynomial-time probabilistic Turing machine equipped with an additional random access proof tape together with a write-only query tape and a read-only answer tape. Two additional states: query state and continue state. The symbols on the proof tape are given by a proof alphabet.

Operation of VVV: relative to the proof π\piπ placed on the proof tape.

Denote VVV together with π\piπ: VπV^\piVπ. During computation VπV^\piVπ can enter the query state at most once.

  • Contents of the query tape is a list of positions of proof tape.
  • Symbols of the proof tape placed in those positions are placed on the answer tape, after which computation resumes in the continue state.

We restrict that only ONE ACCESS to the proof.

Important parameters of PCP verifier:

  1. Number of random bits used during computation
  2. Number of queries made to the proof tape.

📖Definition 49 (PCP languages). Let r:N→N,q:N→Nr:\N\to\N,q:\N\to\Nr:N→N,q:N→N be functions, let Σ\SigmaΣ be a non-empty finite set, and let 0≤s<c≤10\le s\lt c\le10≤s<c≤1 be reals. PCPc,sΣ(r(n),q(n))PCP_{c,s}^\Sigma(r(n),q(n))PCPc,sΣ​(r(n),q(n)) is the class of languages LLL for which there exist a PCP verifier VVV that on input xxx of length nnn uses at most r(n)r(n)r(n) random bits and queries at most q(n)q(n)q(n) positions of a proof π∈Σ∗\pi\in\Sigma^*π∈Σ∗ s.t.

∀x∈L,∃π∈Σ∗:Pr⁡[Vπ(x)=yes]≥c∀x∉L,∃π∈Σ∗:Pr⁡[Vπ(x)=yes]≤s\forall x\in L,\exist\pi\in\Sigma^*:\Pr[V^\pi(x)=yes]\ge c\\\forall x\not\in L,\exist\pi\in\Sigma^*:\Pr[V^\pi(x)=yes]\le s∀x∈L,∃π∈Σ∗:Pr[Vπ(x)=yes]≥c∀x∈L,∃π∈Σ∗:Pr[Vπ(x)=yes]≤s

ccc for completeness, sss for soundness.

We often use the notion as follows:

  • PCPc,s(r(n),q(n))PCP_{c,s}(r(n),q(n))PCPc,s​(r(n),q(n)) when Σ={0,1}\Sigma=\{0,1\}Σ={0,1}
  • PCPΣ(r(n),q(n))PCP^\Sigma(r(n),q(n))PCPΣ(r(n),q(n)) when c=1,s=1/2c=1,s=1/2c=1,s=1/2
  • PCP(r(n),q(n))PCP(r(n),q(n))PCP(r(n),q(n)) when both Σ={0,1}\Sigma=\{0,1\}Σ={0,1} and c=1,s=1/2c=1,s=1/2c=1,s=1/2.

🤔Proposition 17.

  1. P=PCP(0,0)P=PCP(0,0)P=PCP(0,0)
  2. NP=PCP(0,nO(1))NP=PCP(0,n^{O(1)})NP=PCP(0,nO(1))
  3. coRP=PCP(nO(1),0)coRP=PCP(n^{O(1)},0)coRP=PCP(nO(1),0)

By enumerating over all strings of O(log⁡n)O(\log n)O(logn) bits and using these in place of the random bits one obtain the slightly stronger statements P=PCP(O(log⁡n),0)P=PCP(O(\log n),0)P=PCP(O(logn),0) and NP=PCP(O(log⁡n),nO(1))NP=PCP(O(\log n),n^{O(1)})NP=PCP(O(logn),nO(1)).

By enumerating over all possible proofs of length O(log⁡n)O(\log n)O(logn) one obtains P=PCP(0,O(log⁡n))P=PCP(0,O(\log n))P=PCP(0,O(logn)).

Verifier of PCP(r(n),q(n))PCP(r(n),q(n))PCP(r(n),q(n)) is able to access at most 2r(n)q(n)2^{r(n)}q(n)2r(n)q(n) different positions of the proof string π\piπ.

🤔Proposition 18. PCP(r(n),q(n))⊆NTIME(nO(1)2r(n))PCP(r(n),q(n))\subseteq NTIME(n^{O(1)}2^{r(n)})PCP(r(n),q(n))⊆NTIME(nO(1)2r(n)).

🎯Theorem 50 (PCP theorem). NP=PCP(O(log⁡n),O(1))NP=PCP(O(\log n),O(1))NP=PCP(O(logn),O(1)).

🎯Theorem 51. NEXP=PCP(nO(1),nO(1))NEXP=PCP(n^{O(1)},n^{O(1)})NEXP=PCP(nO(1),nO(1)).

A weak version of the PCP theorem

🎯Theorem 52. NP⊆PCP((log⁡n)O(1),(log⁡n)O(1))NP\subseteq PCP((\log n)^{O(1)},(\log n)^{O(1)})NP⊆PCP((logn)O(1),(logn)O(1)).

Some observations about interactive proofs and probabilistically checkable proofs.

  1. Consider an interactive proof system (P,V)(P,V)(P,V). On input xxx, we tabulate all possible replies P(⟨x,m1,⋯ ,mi⟩)P(\lang x,m_1,\cdots,m_i\rang)P(⟨x,m1​,⋯,mi​⟩) a prover PPP may send during a run of the protocol with input xxx into a written proof π\piπ.

    Then verifier VVV may be viewed as an adaptive PCP verifier that instead of communicating with PPP simply queries the proof π\piπ.

    In Sumcheck protocol, all msg of VVV consist of uniformly random bits, which means that all queries may be made non-adaptively. Together with Theorem 49, this gives that IP⊆PCP(nO(1),nO(1))IP\subseteq PCP(n^{O(1)},n^{O(1)})IP⊆PCP(nO(1),nO(1)).

  2. Arithmetic formula FFF in Sumcheck is only evaluated once, at the end of the protocol, and on a uniformly chosen random input (a1,⋯ ,an)∈Zpn(a_1,\cdots,a_n)\in\Z_p^n(a1​,⋯,an​)∈Zpn​.

For proving Theorem 52, we need to show that 3SAT∈PCP((log⁡n)O(1),(log⁡n)O(1))3SAT\in PCP((\log n)^{O(1)},(\log n)^{O(1)})3SAT∈PCP((logn)O(1),(logn)O(1)).

Some details is omitted.

🤔Lemma 18. For any function f:{0,1}ℓ→Rf:\{0,1\}^\ell\to Rf:{0,1}ℓ→R, where RRR is any ring, there is a unique multilinear polynomial f~\tilde ff~​ s.t. f(x)=f~(x)f(x)=\tilde f(x)f(x)=f~​(x) for all x∈{0,1}ℓx\in\{0,1\}^\ellx∈{0,1}ℓ.

🤔Lemma 19. Let f:{0,1}ℓ→{0,1}f:\{0,1\}^\ell\to\{0,1\}f:{0,1}ℓ→{0,1} and let x∈{1,⋯ ,M}ℓx\in\{1,\cdots,M\}^\ellx∈{1,⋯,M}ℓ. Then

∣f~(x)∣≤2ℓMℓ=(2M)ℓ|\tilde f(x)|\le2^\ell M^\ell=(2M)^\ell∣f~​(x)∣≤2ℓMℓ=(2M)ℓ

📖Definition 50. Let φ\varphiφ be a 3CNF3CNF3CNF formula with nnn var and mmm clauses and let functions h1,h2,h3h_1,h_2,h_3h1​,h2​,h3​ and s1,s2,s3s_1,s_2,s_3s1​,s2​,s3​ be defined as above. Let a:{0,1}ℓ→Za:\{0,1\}^\ell\to\Za:{0,1}ℓ→Z be any function. We define the arithmetic formula Aφ,aA_{\varphi,a}Aφ,a​ in 4ℓ4\ell4ℓ variables computing a polynomial of total degree 3(2ℓ+2ℓ)=12ℓ3(2\ell+2\ell)=12\ell3(2ℓ+2ℓ)=12ℓ by

Aφ,a(c,v1,v2,v3)=∏i=13h~i(c,vi)(s~i(c)−a~(vi))2.A_{\varphi,a}(c,v_1,v_2,v_3)=\prod_{i=1}^3\tilde h_i(c,v_i)(\tilde s_i(c)-\tilde a(v_i))^2.Aφ,a​(c,v1​,v2​,v3​)=i=1∏3​h~i​(c,vi​)(s~i​(c)−a~(vi​))2.

We have that a:{0,1}ℓ→Za:\{0,1\}^\ell\to\Za:{0,1}ℓ→Z is an assignment satisfying φ\varphiφ iff

∑(c,v1,v2,v3)∈{0,1}4ℓAφ,a(c,v1,v2,v3)=0.\sum_{(c,v_1,v_2,v_3)\in\{0,1\}^{4\ell}}A_{\varphi,a}(c,v_1,v_2,v_3)=0.(c,v1​,v2​,v3​)∈{0,1}4ℓ∑​Aφ,a​(c,v1​,v2​,v3​)=0.

📖Definition 51. Let fff and ggg be functions in ℓ\ellℓ variables taking values in a set SSS. The normalized Hamming distance d(f,g)d(f,g)d(f,g) between fff and ggg is

d(f,g)=Pr⁡x∈Sℓ[f(x)≠g(x)].d(f,g)=\Pr_{x\in S^\ell}[f(x)\neq g(x)].d(f,g)=x∈SℓPr​[f(x)=g(x)].

📖Definition 52. Let F\mathbb FF be field and let S⊆FS\subseteq\mathbb FS⊆F. We say that a function f:Sℓ→Ff:S^\ell\to\mathbb Ff:Sℓ→F is δ\deltaδ-close to a multilinear polynomial, if there exist a multilinear polynomial PPP in ℓ\ellℓ variables s.t. d(f,P)≤δd(f,P)\le\deltad(f,P)≤δ, viewing PPP as a function P:Sℓ→FP:S^\ell\to\mathbb FP:Sℓ→F.

The aligned full-line test of a function f:Sℓ→Ff:S^\ell\to\mathbb Ff:Sℓ→F consists of the following steps:

  1. Pick i∈[ℓ]i\in[\ell]i∈[ℓ] uniformly at random.
  2. Pick a1,⋯ ,ai−1,ai+1,⋯ ,aℓ∈Sa_1,\cdots,a_{i-1},a_{i+1},\cdots,a_\ell\in Sa1​,⋯,ai−1​,ai+1​,⋯,aℓ​∈S uniformly at random.
  3. Evaluate fff on the set of inputs L={a1,⋯ ,ai−1,b,ai+1,⋯ ,aℓ∣b∈S}L=\{a_1,\cdots,a_{i-1},b,a_{i+1},\cdots,a_\ell|b\in S\}L={a1​,⋯,ai−1​,b,ai+1​,⋯,aℓ​∣b∈S}.
  4. Accept if fL(b)=f(a1,⋯ ,ai−1,b,ai+1,⋯ ,aℓ)f_L(b)=f(a_1,\cdots,a_{i-1},b,a_{i+1},\cdots,a_\ell)fL​(b)=f(a1​,⋯,ai−1​,b,ai+1​,⋯,aℓ​) is a linear function. Otherwise reject.

🎯Theorem 53. Let ∣S∣≥4ℓ+2|S|\ge4\ell+2∣S∣≥4ℓ+2. Let β\betaβ be the probability that the aligned full-line test rejects the function f:Sℓ→Ff:S^\ell\to\mathbb Ff:Sℓ→F. Then either β>18ℓ\beta\gt\frac{1}{8\ell}β>8ℓ1​ or fff is βℓ\beta\ellβℓ-close to a multilinear polynomial.

🤔Corollary 12. Let ∣S∣≤4ℓ+2|S|\le4\ell+2∣S∣≤4ℓ+2 and ϵ≤1/8\epsilon\le1/8ϵ≤1/8. If a function f:Sℓ→Ff:S^\ell\to\mathbb Ff:Sℓ→F is not ϵ\epsilonϵ-close to a multilinear polynomial, the aligned full-line test rejects fff with probability at least ϵ/ℓ\epsilon/\ellϵ/ℓ.

别学了，学不明白的……

entry.title: Fair AI/ML 4 Endeavor to Bridge Gap between 2 and 2.414
entry.content:
We dedicated to solve the open problem left by Greedy Capture: Is there an algorithm that has better PROP guarantee 2≤ρ≤1+22\le\rho\le1+\sqrt22≤ρ≤1+2​?

My Initial Immature Idea

Do some fine-tuning on results of Greedy Capture.

Pseudo code

  1. X←X\getsX← Greedy Capture(N,M,k)(\mathcal N,\mathcal M,k)(N,M,k)
  2. N←∅N\gets\emptyN←∅ // NNN denotes “free” data points
  3. while ∃\exist∃ 2-approximate Block Coalition
    • Nbc←N_{bc}\getsNbc​← all data points in that 2-approx Block Coalition
    • Xbc←X_{bc}\getsXbc​← all cluster centers associated with any data points in NbcN_{bc}Nbc​
    • Naffect←N_{\text{affect}}\getsNaffect​← all data points associated with any cluster centers in XbcX_{bc}Xbc​
    • N←N∪(Naffect╲Nbc)N\gets N\cup(N_{\text{affect}}\diagdown N_{bc})N←N∪(Naffect​╲Nbc​)
    • x∗←x^*\getsx∗← cluster center of 2-approximate Block Coalition
    • X←X╲XbcX\gets X\diagdown X_{bc}X←X╲Xbc​
    • X←X∪{x∗}X\gets X\cup\{x^*\}X←X∪{x∗}
  4. return XXX

Idea is straightforward, directly eliminate 2-approx Block Coalition.

But how to continue, we need to rerun the Greedy Capture at some point.

Improve the Idea

Instead of using Greedy Capture as black box, we do some modification in it.

“Fine-tuning” Greedy Capture

In the while loop of Greedy Capture, we audit whether there exist 2-approx Block Coalition.

If there is one, we open the corresponding cluster center x∗x^*x∗, and fix all ⌈n/k⌉\lceil n/k\rceil⌈n/k⌉ point in the Block Coalition.

Set the fixed radius rbcr_{bc}rbc​, denoting the distance from cluster center of BC to the ⌈n/k⌉\lceil n/k\rceil⌈n/k⌉-th nearest data point.

Open that cluster center.

Then run the Greedy Capture from the scratch neglecting all fixed point. We don’t synchronously increase rbcr_{bc}rbc​ until δ\deltaδ reaches rbcr_{bc}rbc​.

Also auditing the 2-approximate in that Greedy Capture, if there are block coalition related to any point in cluster x∗x^*x∗, we do the same recursively.

Pseudo Code

Fine-tuning Greedy Capture(N,M,k,rbc,x∗)(\mathcal N,\mathcal M,k,r_{bc},x^*)(N,M,k,rbc​,x∗)

Input: N,M,k,rbc,x∗\mathcal N,\mathcal M,k,r_{bc},x^*N,M,k,rbc​,x∗ // rbcr_{bc}rbc​ denotes the fixed radius for 2-block coalition, x∗x^*x∗ denotes the center of 2-block coalition

  1. X←∅,Δ=(δ1,δ2,⋯ ,δm)←(0,0,⋯ ,0),N←NX\gets\empty,\Delta=(\delta_1,\delta_2,\cdots,\delta_m)\gets(0,0,\cdots,0),N\gets\mathcal NX←∅,Δ=(δ1​,δ2​,⋯,δm​)←(0,0,⋯,0),N←N

  2. X←X∪{x∗},δx∗←rbcX\gets X\cup\{x^*\},\delta_{x^*}\gets r_{bc}X←X∪{x∗},δx∗​←rbc​

  3. while N≠∅N\neq\emptyN=∅ do

    • Smoothly and synchronously increase Δ╲δx∗\Delta\diagdown\delta_{x^*}Δ╲δx∗​

    • If δ\deltaδ for other surpass δx∗\delta_{x^*}δx∗​, increase δx∗\delta_{x^*}δx∗​ also.

    • while ∃x∈X\exist x\in X∃x∈X s.t. ∣B(x,δx)∩N∣≥1|B(x,\delta_x)\cap N|\ge1∣B(x,δx​)∩N∣≥1

      • N←N╲B(x,δx)N\gets N\diagdown B(x,\delta_x)N←N╲B(x,δx​)

    • while ∃x∈M╲X\exist x\in\mathcal M\diagdown X∃x∈M╲X s.t. ∣B(x,δx)∩N∣≥⌈n/k⌉|B(x,\delta_x)\cap N|\ge\lceil n/k\rceil∣B(x,δx​)∩N∣≥⌈n/k⌉ do

      • X←X∪{x}X\gets X\cup\{x\}X←X∪{x}
      • N←N╲B(x,δx)N\gets N\diagdown B(x,\delta_x)N←N╲B(x,δx​)

    • while ∃x′∈M╲X\exist x'\in\mathcal M\diagdown X∃x′∈M╲X s.t. x′x'x′ is the center of a 2-block coalition

      • x∗←x′x^*\gets x'x∗←x′

      • rbc←⌈n/k⌉r_{bc}\gets\lceil n/k\rceilrbc​←⌈n/k⌉-th nearest distance from x∗x^*x∗

      • return Fine-tuning Greedy Capture(N,M,k,rbc,x∗)(\mathcal N,\mathcal M,k,r_{bc},x^*)(N,M,k,rbc​,x∗)

  4. return XXX

Important: DOES IT WORK?

It is obvious that if the algorithm terminates, then we can find 2-approximate PROP clustering.

Running on the Example

On the example where no matter how the clustering is, the PROP approximation can not be better than 2. The algorithm exactly returns 2-PROP clustering.

On the example in which 1+21+\sqrt21+2​ is the lower bound for Greedy Capture, The algorithm returns exactly PROP clustering.

Two symmetry parts, n=6,m=4,k=3n=6,m=4,k=3n=6,m=4,k=3.

Consider one part that we only assign one cluster.

  graph TB1(x1)2(x2)3((a1))4((a2))5((a3))1---|1-ε|31---|2.414|41---|1-ε|52---|2.414|32---|1|42---|0.414|5
  • First the algorithm open x1x_1x1​ by Greedy Capture.
  • Fine-tuning part finds that x2x_2x2​ and a2,a3a_2,a_3a2​,a3​ are a 2-approximate block coalition, then fixes them, rerun the Greedy Capture from the scratch.
  • Finally, x1x_1x1​ are no longer opened. It is exactly PROP clustering.

Questions

There are a few question need to be answered.

❓How to prove that the algorithm always terminate?

❓Can this algorithm always find the best PROP clustering among all (mk)\left( \begin{array}{c}m\\k\end{array} \right)(mk​) possible clustering?
entry.summary: We dedicated to solve the open problem left by Greedy Capture: Is there an algorithm that has better PROP guarantee <

entry.title: 丹麦语 DU 3.3 7-8 Arbejdspladskultur
entry.content:
有趣的表达：

tisse i bukserne for at holde varmen 直译：在裤子里撒尿来保持温暖 意译：饮鸩止渴

Johanna, Manu og Anya

skilte -r, -de, -t 吹嘘，炫耀，张贴

pinlig -t, -e 尴尬的

omvendt -, -e 相反

eks. I Indien er det lige omvendt.

titel titlen, titler, titlerne 头衔

hierarki -et, -er, -erne 层次结构；阶层

almindelig -t, -e 常见的，普通的

tvivl -en 怀疑

  • tvivl om at + SÆTNING/NOGET/hv+SÆTNING
  • komme i tvivl

forventning -en, -er, -erne 期望

overholde -r, …holdt, …holdt 遵守

erklæring -en, -er, -erne 声明 = Erklärung

er vant til = vænne sig til 习惯于

egentlig -t, -e 实际上 = eigentlich

rar -t -e 好的，美丽的

Spørgende ledsætninger

Hv-Spørgsmål:

  • Hvem er han?

    Jeg ved ikke, hvem han er.

  • Hvor arbejder han?

    Jeg ved ikke, hvor han arbejder.

  • Hvem leder arbejdet?

    Jeg ved ikke, hvem der leder arbejdet.

  • Hvem betaler?

    Jeg ved ikke, hvem der betaler.

  • Hvilken bluse er pænest?

    Jeg ved ikke, hvilken bluse der er pænest.

⚠️如果问句中动词后面没有主语（对主语进行提问），则关系从句关系代词之后必须加 der。

Ja/nej-Spørgsmål:

  • Har hun arbejde?

    Jeg ved ikke, om hun har arbejde.

Abdul og chefrollen

bygge -r, -de, -t 建造

leder -en, -e, -ne 领导

Han følger derfor nøje med i alt og styrer alle detaljer. 因此，他密切关注一切，管理好每一个细节。

fordele -r, fordelte, fordelt 分配

instruks -en, -er, -erne 指令，指示

udføre -r, udførte, udført 执行

dygtig -t, -e 精通的

behagelig 愉快的，满足的

Fordele og ulemper ved fladt hierarki

fordele og ulemper 优缺点

at vurdere 评价

Jeg synes, det er …

  • vigtigt
  • rigtigt
  • nødvendigt
  • lige meget
  • interessant
  • problematisk
  • forkert
  • udfordrende 具有挑战性的
  • mærkeligt
  • overraskende
  • tåbeligt 愚蠢的
  • rart/dejligt

at begrunde 理由

for

fordi

at uddybe 详细说明

For eksempel + sætning

Et dilemma fra en arbejdsplads

styring -en, -er, -erne 管理，统治

selvstændig -t, -e | -ere, -st 独立的

selvstændighed -en 独立

firma -et, -er, -erne 公司

i begyndelse 在开始

forkert -, -e 不正确地

  • Hun var bange for at gøre noget forkert. 她害怕做一些错事。

vare -r, -de, -t 持续

i gang 正在进行

anrette -r, -de, -t 准备（食物），安排

behagelig -t, -e 令人愉快的，舒服的 = 德语 behaglich

ubehagelig -t, -e 令人不快的，不舒服的

Hvordan du udtrykker uenighed i en samtale

Er det okay at stille mange spørgsmål, når man er ny på en arbejdsplads?

Jeg mener, at det er okay at stille mange spørgsmål. Det er meget naturligt, at man er usikker, når man er startet i et nyt job. Så har man brug for hjælp.

Er det okay at bruge ironi over for mennesker, som man ikke kender så godt?

Jeg synes ikke, at det er okay at bruge ironi over for mennesker, som man ikke kender så godt. Hvis ironien bliver misforstået, så er det ikke så sjovt.

entry.title: 算法和计算复杂度 10 Interactive Proofs
entry.content:
Interactive Turing Machine

📖Definition 44 (interactive Turing machine). An interactive TM MMM is a probabilistic TM equipped also with a write-only query tape and a read-only answer tape, and has two new special states, a query state and a continue state. The symbols allowed on the query and answer tape are given by a communication alphabet Λ\LambdaΛ.

When MMM enters the query state, the contents mmm of the query tape as a message mmm sent by MMM. We say that we send a reply rrr to mmm by performing the following steps: The query tape is reinitialized to a blank tape, the string rrr is placed on the answer tape, and computation of MMM is resumed in the continue state.

Given two interactive TM, consider running both TM on the same input xxx and relaying messages back and forth. In this way we define interactive proof systems having one TM be the verifier VVV, assumed to be Polynomial-time bounded, and the other TM to be the prover PPP, just assume that PPP will always produce a reply to any message received.

P:Λ∗→Λ∗P:\Lambda^*\to\Lambda^*P:Λ∗→Λ∗

Given also a polynomial time interactive TM VVV, denote by (V,P)(x)(V,P)(x)(V,P)(x) the computation of VVV on input xxx where the replies to messages of VVV are determined as follows.

Suppose that VVV enters query states and m1,⋯ ,mim_1,\cdots,m_im1​,⋯,mi​ is the list of all messages sent by VVV. The reply given to the message mim_imi​ is P(⟨x,m1,⋯ ,mi⟩)P(\langle x,m_1,\cdots,m_i\rangle)P(⟨x,m1​,⋯,mi​⟩).

📖Definition 45 (interactive proof system). Let vvv be a polynomial time interactive Turing machine VVV, P:Λ∗→Λ∗P:\Lambda^*\to\Lambda^*P:Λ∗→Λ∗, and let 0≤s<c≤10\le s\lt c\le10≤s<c≤1. We say that the pair (V,P)(V,P)(V,P) is an interactive proof system for LLL with completeness ccc and soundness error sss if:

x\in L\Rarr\Pr[(V,P)(x)=yes]\ge c\\\and\\x\not\in L\Rarr\Pr[(V,\hat P)(x)=yes]\le s\forall \hat P

Define IPIPIP as the class of all languages that has an interactive proof system with completeness 3/43/43/4 and soundness error 1/41/41/4. We say that VVV is the verifier and PPP the prover of the interactive proof system (V,P)(V,P)(V,P).

We can view NPNPNP as a proof system without randomness or interaction other than a single message.

🤔Proposition 14. NP⊆IPNP\subseteq IPNP⊆IP.

An example of a non-trivial interactive proof system for checking that two graph are not isomorphic (GNIGNIGNI).

GNI 问题：判断两图是否不是同构的。

Given a graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E) and a permutation π:V→V\pi:V\to Vπ:V→V. Denote by π(G)\pi(G)π(G) the graph with vertex set VVV and edge set {(π(u),π(v))∣(u,v)∈E}\{(\pi(u),\pi(v))\vert(u,v)\in E\}{(π(u),π(v))∣(u,v)∈E}.

We say that graphs G1(V,E1),G2(V,E2)G_1(V,E_1),G_2(V,E_2)G1​(V,E1​),G2​(V,E2​) with the same set of vertices are isomorphic, denoted G1≅G2G_1\cong G_2G1​≅G2​, if there exist a permutation π\piπ of VVV s.t. π(G1)=G2\pi(G_1)=G_2π(G1​)=G2​.

Problem of GNIGNIGNI:

  • Instance: Graphs G1(V,E1),G2(V,E2)G_1(V,E_1),G_2(V,E_2)G1​(V,E1​),G2​(V,E2​) on the same set of vertices VVV
  • Question: Is π(G1)≠G2\pi(G_1)\neq G_2π(G1​)=G2​ for all permutations π\piπ of VVV?

Clearly, GNI∈coNPGNI\in coNPGNI∈coNP. It is not known whether GNI∈NPGNI\in NPGNI∈NP.

A very interesting property of this proof system is that it is a so-called zero-knowledge proof.

零知识证明，扯到密码学上去

🎯Theorem 48. GNI∈IPGNI\in IPGNI∈IP.

GMW Protocol for GNIGNIGNI:

  • Input: G1=(V,E1),G2=(V,E2)G_1=(V,E_1),G_2=(V,E_2)G1​=(V,E1​),G2​=(V,E2​).
  • Goal: Prove G1≇G2G_1\not\cong G_2G1​≅G2​.

VVV: Pick i∈{1,2}i\in\{1,2\}i∈{1,2} and permutation π\piπ of VVV uniformly at random. Send H=π(Gi)H=\pi(G_i)H=π(Gi​) to PPP.

PPP: Pick j∈{1,2}j\in\{1,2\}j∈{1,2} s.t. H≅GjH\cong G_jH≅Gj​. Send jjj to VVV.

VVV: Accept if i=ji=ji=j. Otherwise reject.

这个 GMW 协议是什么意思：验证器随机选一个图并将边的编号打乱（记为 HHH），发送给证明器。证明器从两个原图中随便选一个和 HHH 同构的图，将其编号发回验证器。验证器验证同构图编号是否与 HHH 对应原图的编号相等。如果不相等的话，那就认为给定的俩图不同构。

Suppose first G1≇G2G_1\not\cong G_2G1​≅G2​. In this case PPP has a unique choice of jjj s.t. H≇GjH\not\cong G_jH≅Gj​, which means that i=ji=ji=j making VVV accept with probability 111. Suppose next that G1≅V2G_1\cong V_2G1​≅V2​. Then the distribution of π(H)\pi(H)π(H) is independent of iii since the composition of a fixed permutation with a uniformly random permutation is again a uniformly random permutation.

Now since P^\hat PP^ chooses jjj based only on HHH we have Pr⁡[i=j]=1/2\Pr[i=j]=1/2Pr[i=j]=1/2. It follows that the completeness of the protocol is 111 and the soundness error of the protocol is 1/21/21/2. The soundness error may be reduced to 2−k2^{-k}2−k by iterating protocol kkk times.

It is not known whether GNI∈NPGNI\in NPGNI∈NP.

🤔Proposition 15. IP∈PSPACEIP\in PSPACEIP∈PSPACE.

Hard proof.

The Sumcheck Protocol

How to utilize the power of interactive proofs? Converting Boolean formulas to arithmetic formulas and exploit that polynomials can be evaluated on inputs outside the Boolean cube.

Arithmetization: The process of converting a Boolean formula into an arithmetic formula.

By arithmetization, we can prove that P#P⊆IPP^{\#P}\subseteq IPP#P⊆IP, where #P\#P#P is a class capturing the complexity of counting the number of satisfying assignments of a Boolean formula.

A weaker result: coNP⊆IPcoNP\subseteq IPcoNP⊆IP.

The method can be generalized to show PSPACE⊆IPPSPACE\subseteq IPPSPACE⊆IP.

📖Definition 46 (Arithmetization). Let φ\varphiφ be a 3CNF3CNF3CNF formula with mmm classes C1,⋯ ,CmC_1,\cdots,C_mC1​,⋯,Cm​ and nnn variables x1,⋯ ,xnx_1,\cdots,x_nx1​,⋯,xn​. We define the arithmetic formula AφA_\varphiAφ​, aka arithmetization of φ\varphiφ, recursively. For a variable xix_ixi​ we let A(xi)=xiA(x_i)=x_iA(xi​)=xi​, for a negated variable ¬xi\neg x_i¬xi​ we let A(¬xi)=1−xiA(\neg x_i)=1-x_iA(¬xi​)=1−xi​. For a clause C_j=(\ell_{j,1}\or\ell_{j,2}\or\ell_{j,3}) we let

A(Cj)=1−A(¬Cj)=1−A(¬ℓj,1)A(¬ℓj,2)A(¬ℓj,3)=1−(1−A(ℓj,1))(1−A(ℓj,2))(1−A(ℓj,3))A(C_j)=1-A(\neg C_j)=1-A(\neg \ell_{j,1})A(\neg \ell_{j,2})A(\neg \ell_{j,3})\\=1-(1-A(\ell_{j,1}))(1-A(\ell_{j,2}))(1-A(\ell_{j,3}))A(Cj​)=1−A(¬Cj​)=1−A(¬ℓj,1​)A(¬ℓj,2​)A(¬ℓj,3​)=1−(1−A(ℓj,1​))(1−A(ℓj,2​))(1−A(ℓj,3​))

Finally, we define Aφ=∏j=1mA(Cj)A_\varphi=\prod_{j=1}^mA(C_j)Aφ​=∏j=1m​A(Cj​).

Expanding A(φ)A(\varphi)A(φ) into a sum of monomials would take exponential time.

The number of satisfying assignments #φ\#\varphi#φ of φ\varphiφ:

#φ=∑x1=01∑x2=01⋯∑xn=01Aφ(x1,⋯ ,xn)\#\varphi=\sum_{x_1=0}^1\sum_{x_2=0}^1\cdots\sum_{x_n=0}^1A_\varphi(x_1,\cdots,x_n)#φ=x1​=0∑1​x2​=0∑1​⋯xn​=0∑1​Aφ​(x1​,⋯,xn​)

Then we define an interactive proof for proving #φ=K\#\varphi=K#φ=K, for given KKK. For K=0K=0K=0 allow us prove that coNP⊆IPcoNP\subseteq IPcoNP⊆IP. The protocol is called Sumcheck protocol:

  • Input: Arithmetic formula F(x1,⋯ ,xn)F(x_1,\cdots,x_n)F(x1​,⋯,xn​) of total degree ddd, prime ppp, number KKK.
  • Goal: Prove ∑x1=01∑x2=01⋯∑xn=01F(x1,⋯ ,xn)≡Kmod  p\sum_{x_1=0}^1\sum_{x_2=0}^1\cdots\sum_{x_n=0}^1F(x_1,\cdots,x_n)\equiv K\mod p∑x1​=01​∑x2​=01​⋯∑xn​=01​F(x1​,⋯,xn​)≡Kmodp.
  • Verifier: If n=0n=0n=0, evaluate the arithmetic formula FFF, which only have constants as inputs. Accept it F≡Kmod  pF\equiv K\mod pF≡Kmodp and reject otherwise. If N≥1N\ge1N≥1, await message from PPP.
  • Prover: Send the uni-variate degree ddd polynomial Q(x1)Q(x_1)Q(x1​) to Verifier, where Q(x1)Q(x_1)Q(x1​) is given by Q(x1)=∑x2=01⋯∑xn=01F(x1,⋯ ,xn)Q(x_1)=\sum_{x_2=0}^1\cdots\sum_{x_n=0}^1F(x_1,\cdots,x_n)Q(x1​)=∑x2​=01​⋯∑xn​=01​F(x1​,⋯,xn​).
  • Verifier: If Q(0)+Q(1)≢Kmod  pQ(0)+Q(1)\not\equiv K\mod pQ(0)+Q(1)≡Kmodp, reject. Otherwise, pick a1∈Zpa_1\in\mathbb Z_pa1​∈Zp​ uniformly at random. Send a1a_1a1​ to PPP and recursively invoke the protocol for proving that ∑x2=01⋯∑xn=01F(a1,x2,⋯ ,xn)≡Q(a1)mod  p\sum_{x_2=0}^1\cdots\sum_{x_n=0}^1F(a_1,x_2,\cdots,x_n)\equiv Q(a_1)\mod p∑x2​=01​⋯∑xn​=01​F(a1​,x2​,⋯,xn​)≡Q(a1​)modp.

🤔Proposition 16. Let F(x1,⋯ ,xn)F(x_1,\cdots,x_n)F(x1​,⋯,xn​) be an arithmetic formula of total degree ddd, which is polynomial in nnn, let ppp be a prime of bi-length polynomial in nnn, and let KKK be an integer. The Sumcheck protocol is an interactive proof for the statement

∑x1=01∑x2=01⋯∑xn=01F(x1,⋯ ,xn)≡Kmod  p\sum_{x_1=0}^1\sum_{x_2=0}^1\cdots\sum_{x_n=0}^1F(x_1,\cdots,x_n)\equiv K\mod px1​=0∑1​x2​=0∑1​⋯xn​=0∑1​F(x1​,⋯,xn​)≡Kmodp

with completeness 111 and soundness error at most nd/pnd/pnd/p.

🤔Corollary 11. coNP⊆IPcoNP\subseteq IPcoNP⊆IP.

Show that 3SAT‾∈IP\overline{3SAT}\in IP3SAT∈IP.

Interactive Proof for Polynomial Space

PSPACE⊆IPPSPACE\subseteq IPPSPACE⊆IP

Consider PSPACEPSPACEPSPACE-complete TQBFTQBFTQBF.

Consider whether ψ=∃x1∈{0,1}∀x2∈{0,1}⋯∃xn∈{0,1}φ(x1,⋯ ,xn)\psi=\exist x_1\in\{0,1\}\forall x_2\in\{0,1\}\cdots\exist x_n\in\{0,1\}\varphi(x_1,\cdots,x_n)ψ=∃x1​∈{0,1}∀x2​∈{0,1}⋯∃xn​∈{0,1}φ(x1​,⋯,xn​) is true.

WLOG, quantifiers are strictly alternating, φ\varphiφ is a 3CNF3CNF3CNF formula with nnn variables and mmm clauses.

Note that ψ\psiψ is true iff

∑x1∏x2∑x3⋯∑xnAφ(x1,⋯ ,xn)>0.\sum_{x_1}\prod_{x_2}\sum_{x_3}\cdots\sum_{x_n}A_\varphi(x_1,\cdots,x_n)\gt0.x1​∑​x2​∏​x3​∑​⋯xn​∑​Aφ​(x1​,⋯,xn​)>0.

Unbinding outermost summation over x1x_1x1​ is polynomial of exponential degree.

One solution to around the obstacle: limiting the scope of each variable using variable renaming.

Making use of linearization for the same purpose:

📖Definition 47. Let Q(x1,⋯ ,xn)Q(x_1,\cdots,x_n)Q(x1​,⋯,xn​) be a polynomial. By Lxi\large\mathbf L_{x_i}Lxi​​ binds the variable xix_ixi​, at the same time introducing a new variable xix_ixi​ (reusing the variable name xix_ixi​). Now replace the condition ∑x1∏x2∑x3⋯∑xnAφ(x1,⋯ ,xn)>0\sum_{x_1}\prod_{x_2}\sum_{x_3}\cdots\sum_{x_n}A_\varphi(x_1,\cdots,x_n)\gt0∑x1​​∏x2​​∑x3​​⋯∑xn​​Aφ​(x1​,⋯,xn​)>0 by

∑x1Lx1∑x2Lx1Lx2⋯∑xnLx1⋯LxnAφ(x1,⋯ ,xn)>0.\sum_{x_1}\mathbf L_{x_1}\sum_{x_2}\mathbf L_{x_1}\mathbf L_{x_2}\cdots\sum_{x_n}\mathbf L_{x_1}\cdots\mathbf L_{x_n}A_\varphi(x_1,\cdots,x_n)\gt0.x1​∑​Lx1​​x2​∑​Lx1​​Lx2​​⋯xn​∑​Lx1​​⋯Lxn​​Aφ​(x1​,⋯,xn​)>0.

The extension of the Sumcheck protocol:

  • The prover sends a prime ppp and a number K≢0mod  pK\not\equiv0\mod pK≡0modp s.t. the LHS is K mod pK\text{ mod }pK mod p.

    The LHS is a non-negative integer of magnitude at most 22n2^{2^n}22n, hence is divisible by ay most 2n2^n2n distinct primes.

    By property of prime distribution function, the prime ppp has bit-length n+O(log⁡n)n+O(\log n)n+O(logn).

  • Each of the operators of the form ∑xi,∏xi,Lxi\sum_{x_i},\prod_{x_i},\mathbf L_{x_i}∑xi​​,∏xi​​,Lxi​​ are unbound one by one, and PPP sends the resulting uni-variate polynomial Q(xi)Q(x_i)Q(xi​).

  • …

🎯Theorem 49. IP=PSPACEIP=PSPACEIP=PSPACE.

Two interesting observation:

  1. The completeness of the extended Sumcheck protocol is 111. Any interactive proof system may be converted into an equivalent interactive proof system with completeness 111.
  2. The message sent to the Prover by the Verifier may be viewed as just consisting of all random bits read since the last message sent.

entry.title: Fair AI/ML 3 PROP Fair Clustering Revisited
entry.content:
Read the paper Proportionally Fair Clustering Revisited by Micha et Shah.

kkk cluster centers must be placed given nnn points in a metric space.

The cost to each point is its distance to the nearest cluster center.

This paper: Focus on the case where cluster centers can be placed anywhere in metric space.

E.g. L2L^2L2 distance over Rt\mathbb R^tRt, the approximation ratio of greedy capture improves to 222.

For L1,L∞L^1,L^\inftyL1,L∞ metric, the approximation ratio remains 1+21+\sqrt 21+2​.

The paper gives universal lower bounds which apply to all algorithms.

Introduction

Points N\mathcal NN, possible cluster centers M\mathcal MM.

Given k∈Nk\in\mathbb Nk∈N, task is to select a set X⊆MX\subseteq\mathcal MX⊆M consisting of ∣X∣=k|X|=k∣X∣=k cluster centers.

Group fairness.

Proportional fairness.

Contribution

Focus on the case where the metric consists of usual distance functions such as L1,L2,L∞L^1,L^2,L^\inftyL1,L2,L∞ over Rt\mathbb R^tRt.

⚠️Cluster centers can be placed anywhere in the infinite metric space. M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt❗

请注意此处，候选聚类中心和上一篇论文不一样，所以得出的近似下界不一样。

Greedy Capture by Chen et al. where d∈{L1,L2,L∞}d\in\{L^1,L^2,L^\infty\}d∈{L1,L2,L∞} and M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt.

For d=L2,M=Rtd=L^2,\mathcal M=\mathbb R^td=L2,M=Rt, GC provides 222-PROP. The approximation is obtained by Apollonius radius.

For L1,L∞L^1,L^\inftyL1,L∞, the approximation ratio can not be better than 1+21+\sqrt21+2​.

Universal lower bounds: for d=L2d=L^2d=L2 and M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt, no algorithm achieves better than 23≈1.155\frac{2}{\sqrt 3}\approx1.1553​2​≈1.155-PROP, whereas for d∈{L1,L∞}d\in\{L^1,L^\infty\}d∈{L1,L∞} and M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt, the lower bound is 1.41.41.4.

Also, this paper consider the case where M\mathcal MM is the set of nodes of an unweighted graph, and ddd measures the shortest distance between two nodes on the graph.

  • If the graph is a tree, then PROP must exist. And there are an efficient algorithm.
  • If the graph is arbitrary, k≥n/2k\ge n/2k≥n/2. PROP must exist and can be computed efficiently.
  • Open problem: Whether an exact PROP exists for all graphs.

For d=L2d=L^2d=L2 and M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt for t≥2t\ge2t≥2, checking whether a clustering is PROP is NP-hard.

When ttt is large,even greedy capture is NP-hard. When ttt is constant, the problem becomes efficiently solvable.

When ttt is large, using a PTASPTASPTAS as sub-routine of greedy capture, we can efficiently compute 2(1+ϵ)2(1+\epsilon)2(1+ϵ)-PROP fair clustering for any fixed ϵ>0\epsilon\gt0ϵ>0

Problem of generalization: Would a clustering that is PROP w.r.t. samples drawn from N\mathcal NN remain approximately PROP w.r.t. entire set N\mathcal NN? Chen et al. proved that the answer is yes when ∣M∣|\mathcal M|∣M∣ is finite. Using the VC dimension, the answer is also yes for M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt.

Preliminaries

N\mathcal NN: the set of nnn data points lie in a metric space (X,d)(\mathcal X,d)(X,d), where d:X×X→Rd:\mathcal X\times\mathcal X\to\mathbb Rd:X×X→R is a distance function satisfying the triangle inequality.

Consider X=Rt\mathcal X=\mathbb R^tX=Rt for t∈Nt\in\mathbb Nt∈N.

Distance function: L2,L1,L∞L^2,L^1,L^\inftyL2,L1,L∞.

M\mathcal MM: set of candidate cluster centers. In this paper M=X\mathcal M=\mathcal XM=X.

Given k∈Nk\in\mathbb Nk∈N, a kkk-clustering is a set X∈MkX\in\mathcal M^kX∈Mk.

Each x∈Xx\in Xx∈X is called the open cluster center.

Cost to agent i∈Ni\in\mathcal Ni∈N induced by a cluster center x∈Mx\in\mathcal Mx∈M is the distance d(i,x)d(i,x)d(i,x). The cost to agent iii should be the minimal distance.

d(i,X)=min⁡x∈Xd(i,x)d(i,X)=\min_{x\in X}d(i,x)d(i,X)=x∈Xmin​d(i,x)

Agent iii is interested in minimizing the cost.

A set of points S⊆NS\subseteq NS⊆N containing at least ⌈n/k⌉\lceil n/k\rceil⌈n/k⌉, if they can find a new cluster that is better for each of them, it is a violation of fairness (block coalition)

📖Definition 1. ρ\rhoρ-PROP, block coalition. Omitted.

PROP on graphs: given an undirected graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E), N⊆V,M=V\mathcal N\subseteq V,\mathcal M=VN⊆V,M=V. Distance between u,v∈Vu,v\in Vu,v∈V is the length of the shortest path.

Greedy Capture

Detail is omitted here.

(1+2)(1+\sqrt2)(1+2​)-PROP

This paper gives a refined analysis of Greedy Capture.

📖Definition 2 (Apollonius radius) Given ρ≥1\rho\ge1ρ≥1, the ρ\rhoρ-Apollonius radius of a metric (X,d)(\mathcal X,d)(X,d) is defined as AX,d(ρ)=sup⁡x,y∈XΔ(ρ,x,y)/d(x,y)A_{\mathcal X,d}(\rho)=\sup_{x,y\in\mathcal X}\Delta(\rho,x,y)/d(x,y)AX,d​(ρ)=supx,y∈X​Δ(ρ,x,y)/d(x,y), where Δ(ρ,x,y)\Delta(\rho,x,y)Δ(ρ,x,y) is the radius of the smallest ball centered at some point in X\mathcal XX that contains the entire set {p∈X:ρ⋅d(p,y)≤d(p,x)}\{p\in\mathcal X:\rho\cdot d(p,y)\le d(p,x)\}{p∈X:ρ⋅d(p,y)≤d(p,x)}.

When ρ>1\rho\gt1ρ>1, the set is a ball.

🎯Theorem 3. For any metric (X,d)(\mathcal X,d)(X,d) and M=X\mathcal M=\mathcal XM=X, greedy capture finds a ρ\rhoρ-PROP clustering, where ρ≥1\rho\ge1ρ≥1 is the smallest positive number satisfying AX,d(ρ)⋅ρ+1ρ≤1A_{\mathcal X,d}(\rho)\cdot\frac{\rho+1}{\rho}\le1AX,d​(ρ)⋅ρρ+1​≤1.

M=X\mathcal M=\mathcal XM=X: 候选聚类中心可以是空间上任意一点。

Proof by triangle inequality. Proof that if XXX is not ρ\rhoρ-PROP, then AX,d(ρ)⋅ρ+1ρ>1A_{\mathcal X,d}(\rho)\cdot\frac{\rho+1}{\rho}\gt1AX,d​(ρ)⋅ρρ+1​>1.

🎯Theorem 4. For any metric (X,d)(\mathcal X,d)(X,d), the ρ\rhoρ-Apollonius radius is AX,d(ρ)≤1ρ−1A_{\mathcal X,d}(\rho)\le\frac{1}{\rho-1}AX,d​(ρ)≤ρ−11​. Hence, greedy capture finds a (1+2)(1+\sqrt2)(1+2​)-PROP fair clustering for every metric.

在我看来，本篇论文定义了一个复杂的概念——阿波罗尼乌斯半径，来形式化证明算法结果的下界。

但是这个阿波罗尼乌斯半径的定义过于复杂了。

Next, the paper shows for d=L2d=L^2d=L2, the ρ\rhoρ-Apollonius radius is better, 222-PROP guarantee.

🎯Theorem 5. For the metric space (R2,L2)(\mathbb R^2,L^2)(R2,L2), where t∈Nt\in\mathbb Nt∈N, the ρ\rhoρ-Apollonius radius AR2,L2(ρ)≤ρρ2−1A_{\mathbb R^2,L^2}(\rho)\le\frac{\rho}{\rho^2-1}AR2,L2​(ρ)≤ρ2−1ρ​, and hence, greedy capture finds a 222-PROP clustering.

Proof omitted.

Whether the introduction of Apollonius improves approximation bound for other distance metrics. For L1,L∞L^1,L^\inftyL1,L∞, the answer is unfortunately NO. The approximation remains 1+21+\sqrt 21+2​.

🎯Theorem 6. For the metric space (Rt,d)(\mathbb R^t,d)(Rt,d) where t≥2t\ge2t≥2 and d∈{L1,L∞}d\in\{L^1,L^\infty\}d∈{L1,L∞}, and M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt, there exists an example in which the clustering produced by greedy capture is not ρ\rhoρ-PROP for ρ<1+2\rho\lt1+\sqrt2ρ<1+2​.

Universal Lower Bounds

This paper generalizes lower bounds on approximation to PROP that apply to ALL ALGORITHMS.

Chen et al. showed that ρ<2\rho<2ρ<2 is not guaranteed. For N=M\mathcal N=\mathcal MN=M, the weaker lower bound 1.51.51.5.

This paper: for the case where M=X=Rt\mathcal M=\mathcal X=\mathbb R^tM=X=Rt and d∈{L1,L2,L∞}d\in\{L^1,L^2,L^\infty\}d∈{L1,L2,L∞}.

再次提醒：M=X\mathcal M=\mathcal XM=X: 候选聚类中心可以是空间上任意一点。

  • When t=1t=1t=1, it’s easy to see that there always exist PROP clusterings.
  • When t≥2t\ge2t≥2, a lower bound 2/32/\sqrt32/3​ for d=L2d=L^2d=L2 and a lower bound 1.41.41.4 for d∈{L1,L∞}d\in\{L^1,L^\infty\}d∈{L1,L∞}.

🎯Theorem 7. For the metric space (Rt,L2)(\mathbb R^t,L^2)(Rt,L2) where t≥2t\ge2t≥2 and M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt, there is an example in which no clustering is ρ\rhoρ-PROP for p<2/3≈1.155p\lt2/\sqrt3\approx1.155p<2/3​≈1.155.

Closing the gap between lower bound 1.1551.1551.155 and upper bound 222 for L2L^2L2 is an open problem.

🎯Theorem 8. For the metric space (Rt,d)(\mathbb R^t,d)(Rt,d), where t≥2t\ge2t≥2 and d∈{L1,L∞}d\in\{L^1,L^\infty\}d∈{L1,L∞}, and M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt, there is an example in which no clustering is ρ\rhoρ-PROP for ρ<1.4\rho\lt1.4ρ<1.4.

Clustering in Graphs

In this section, we consider the special case where the metric space (X,d)(\mathcal X,d)(X,d) is induced by an undirected graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E).

Consider the case of M=X=V\mathcal M=\mathcal X=VM=X=V. Distance d(x,y)d(x,y)d(x,y) is the length of the shortest path between x,yx,yx,y.

所有节点都是候选聚类中心，距离定义为最短路长度。

When GGG is a tree, an exact PROP clustering always exists, and can be computed by an efficient algorithm.

PROP Clustering for Trees

First root the tree at an arbitrary node rrr to obtain a rooted tree (G,r)(G,r)(G,r).

Denote with hhh the height of the rooted rooted tree, and with level(x)level(x)level(x) the height of node xxx relative to root rrr with level(r)=1level(r)=1level(r)=1.

Let ST(x)ST(x)ST(x) denote the sub-tree of node xxx

The algorithm starts from the leaves, opens a center every time it finds a node whose sub-tree contains at least ⌈n/k⌉\lceil n/k\rceil⌈n/k⌉ nodes, then deletes this sub-tree from the graph. At the end, the cost to each node is still defined using the closest node at which a center is opened by the algorithm.

Pseudo Code - PROP Clustering for Trees

  1. Root the tree GGG at an arbitrary node rrr.
  2. X←∅X\gets\emptyX←∅
  3. Gd←GG^d\gets GGd←G.
  4. for ℓ=d\ell=dℓ=d to 111 do
    1. Gℓ−1=GℓG^{\ell-1}=G^\ellGℓ−1=Gℓ
    2. for every x∈Vx\in Vx∈V with level(x)=llevel(x)=llevel(x)=l and ∣ST(x)∣≥⌈n/k⌉|ST(x)|\ge\lceil n/k\rceil∣ST(x)∣≥⌈n/k⌉ do
      • X←X∪{x}X\gets X\cup\{x\}X←X∪{x}
      • Gℓ−1←Gℓ−1╲ST(x)G^{\ell-1}\gets G^{\ell-1}\diagdown ST(x)Gℓ−1←Gℓ−1╲ST(x)
  5. if G0≠∅G^0\neq\emptyG0=∅ then X←X∪{r}X\gets X\cup\{r\}X←X∪{r}
  6. return XXX

🎯Theorem 9. Let G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E) be an undirected tree, (V,d)(V,d)(V,d) be the metric induced by GGG, N⊆V,M=V\mathcal N\subseteq V,\mathcal M=VN⊆V,M=V, and k∈Nk\in\mathbb Nk∈N. Then, the algorithm yields a PROP clustering.

Hard proof by contradiction.

What about Non-tree

Consider the universal lower bound for (R2,L1)(\mathbb R^2,L^1)(R2,L1) metric from Theorem 8.

If the graph is dense enough, we can derive same lower bound of 1.41.41.4.

❓Whether better lower bounds exist is an open problem.

❓For special case where N=V\mathcal N=VN=V, we do not know whether PROP always exists

If GGG is connected and we want to place a large number of clusters k≥n/2k\ge n/2k≥n/2, then PROP always exists. This is because a dominating set of any size k≥n/2k\ge n/2k≥n/2 is guaranteed to exist in a graph with nnn nodes and can be computed efficiently.

Definition of dominating set: A set of nodes is called a dominating set if every node in the graph is either in this set or adjacent to a node in this set.

Thus the problem of finding a PROP clustering in general graphs with N=M=V\mathcal N=\mathcal M=VN=M=V is trivial when k≥n/2k\ge n/2k≥n/2, but remains open when k<n/2k\lt n/2k<n/2.

Computational Aspects

Two problems:

  1. Checking whether a PROP clustering exits.
  2. Implementing the Greedy Capture when M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt.

🎯Theorem 10, Given a finite N\mathcal NN, finite M\mathcal MM, k∈Nk\in\mathbb Nk∈N, and d=L2d=L^2d=L2, checking whether a PROP clustering exists is NP-hard.

Polynomial-time reduction from the planar monotone rectilinear 3-SAT problem.

Planar monotone rectilinear 3-SAT problem: Given a 3-SAT formula, each clause cjc_jcj​ consists of only positive or only negative literals, the graph connecting clauses to literals they contain is planar, and this graph has a planar embedding in which each variable viv_ivi​ is represented by a rectangle on the xxx-axis and each positive/negative clause is represented by a rectangle above/below xxx-axis with 3 vertical lines or legs to its 3 variables.

什么玩意啊，什么乱七八糟的 NP-hard 问题。欺负我不会证规约是吧。

🎯Theorem 11. Let t∈Nt\in\mathbb Nt∈N, finite N⊂Rt\mathcal N\subset\mathbb R^tN⊂Rt, and k∈Nk\in\mathbb Nk∈N be given as input. Suppose M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt and d=L2d=L^2d=L2. Then, the following hold:

  1. The clustering returned by Greedy Capture algorithm cannot be computed in polynomial time unless P=NPP=NPP=NP.
  2. If ttt is constant, then it can be computed in polynomial time.
  3. Even if ttt is not constant, for any constant ϵ>0\epsilon>0ϵ>0, there exists a polynomial time algorithm which finds a (2+ϵ)(2+\epsilon)(2+ϵ)-PROP clustering.

Learning Fair Clustering by Sampling

VERY DIFFICULT!

Is a clustering that is approximately PROP w.r.t. random samples taken from an underlying population would remain approximately PROP w.r.t. the whole population.

YES!

📖Definition 12. We say that a kkk-clustering XXX is ρ\rhoρ-PROP fair to (1+ϵ)(1+\epsilon)(1+ϵ)-deviations w.r.t. N\mathcal NN if for all S⊆NS\subseteq\mathcal NS⊆N with ∣S∣≥∣N∣⋅(1+ϵ)/k|S|\ge|\mathcal N|\cdot(1+\epsilon)/k∣S∣≥∣N∣⋅(1+ϵ)/k and all y∈My\in\mathcal My∈M, there exists at least one i∈Si\in Si∈S s.t. ρ⋅d(i,y)≥d(i,X)\rho\cdot d(i,y)\ge d(i,X)ρ⋅d(i,y)≥d(i,X).

📖Definition 13. Given a set of points N\mathcal NN, a kkk-clustering XXX, and y∈My\in\mathcal My∈M, define the binary classifier hX,y:N→{0,1}h_{X,y}:\mathcal N\to\{0,1\}hX,y​:N→{0,1} s.t. hX,y(i)=1h_{X,y}(i)=1hX,y​(i)=1 iff ρ⋅d(i,y)<d(i,X)\rho\cdot d(i,y)\lt d(i,X)ρ⋅d(i,y)<d(i,X). Define the error of this classifier on a set of points S⊆NS\subseteq\mathcal NS⊆N as errS(hX,y)=(1/∣S∣)⋅∑i∈ShX,y(i)err_S(h_{X,y})=(1/|S|)\cdot\sum_{i\in S}h_{X,y}(i)errS​(hX,y​)=(1/∣S∣)⋅∑i∈S​hX,y​(i).

The classifier equals 111 iff iii can be part of a coalition that complains about the unfairness of XXX by demonstrating yyy as a location that provides them ρ\rhoρ-improvement.

XXX is ρ\rhoρ-PROP to (1+ϵ)(1+\epsilon)(1+ϵ)-deviations w.r.t. N\mathcal NN iff errN(X,y)≤1+ϵkerr_\mathcal N(X,y)\le\frac{1+\epsilon}{k}errN​(X,y)≤k1+ϵ​ for all y∈My\in\mathcal My∈M.

Goal: Show that given a large enough random simple N⊆NN\subseteq\mathcal NN⊆N, if we have clustering XXX that is ρ\rhoρ-PROP w.r.t. NNN, then it is ρ\rhoρ-PROP to (1+ϵ)(1+\epsilon)(1+ϵ)-deviations w.r.t. N\mathcal NN with high probability. But there is no control over X,yX,yX,y. Because of the uniform convergence guarantee.

∣errN(hX,y)−errN(hX,y)∣|err_N(h_{X,y})-err_\mathcal N(h_{X,y})|∣errN​(hX,y​)−errN​(hX,y​)∣ is bounded for all X,yX,yX,y.

📖Definition 14 (VC Dimension). Let N\mathcal NN be a set of points. Let H\mathcal HH be a family of binary classifier over N\mathcal NN. We say that H\mathcal HH shatters S⊆NS\subseteq\mathcal NS⊆N if for every labeling ℓ:S→{0,1}\ell:S\to\{0,1\}ℓ:S→{0,1}, there exists a classifier h∈Hh\in\mathcal Hh∈H s.t. h(i)=ℓ(i)h(i)=\ell(i)h(i)=ℓ(i) for all i∈Si\in Si∈S. The VC dimension of H\mathcal HH, denoted dimVC(H)dim^{VC}(\mathcal H)dimVC(H), is the size of the largest SSS that can be shattered by H\mathcal HH.

🤔Proposition 15. Let H\mathcal HH be a family of binary classifier over a set of points N\mathcal NN. If N⊆NN\subseteq NN⊆N is a uniformly random sample with ∣N∣≥Ω(dimVC(H)+ln⁡(1/δ)ϵ2)|N|\ge\Omega\left(\frac{dim^{VC}(\mathcal H)+\ln(1/\delta)}{\epsilon^2}\right)∣N∣≥Ω(ϵ2dimVC(H)+ln(1/δ)​), then with probability at least 1−δ1-\delta1−δ, ∣errN(h)−errN(h)∣≤ϵ|err_N(h)-err_\mathcal N(h)|\le\epsilon∣errN​(h)−errN​(h)∣≤ϵ for all h∈Hh\in\mathcal Hh∈H.

🎯Theorem 16. Fix ϵ,δ>0,ρ≥1,k,t∈N\epsilon,\delta\gt0,\rho\ge1,k,t\in\Nϵ,δ>0,ρ≥1,k,t∈N, and metric (X,d)(\mathcal X,d)(X,d) where X=Rt\mathcal X=\R^tX=Rt and d=L2d=L^2d=L2. Let N\mathcal NN be a set of points and M=Rt\mathcal M=\R^tM=Rt be the set of candidate centers. Let N⊆NN\subseteq\mathcal NN⊆N be sampled uniformly at random with ∣N∣≥Ω(k2⋅(tkln⁡k+ln⁡(1/δ))ϵ2)|N|\ge\Omega\left(\frac{k^2\cdot(tk\ln k+\ln(1/\delta))}{\epsilon^2}\right)∣N∣≥Ω(ϵ2k2⋅(tklnk+ln(1/δ))​). Then with probability at least 1−δ1-\delta1−δ, every kkk-clustering X∈MkX\in\mathcal M^kX∈Mk that is ρ\rhoρ-PROP w.r.t. NNN is ρ\rhoρ-PROP to (1+ϵ)(1+\epsilon)(1+ϵ)-deviation w.r.t. N\mathcal NN.

Open Questions

This paper mainly consider M\mathcal MM is entire metric space.

There are some open questions.

Bridging Gaps

Can we bridge the lower (1+2)(1+\sqrt2)(1+2​) and upper bounds on the approximation ratio to PROP.

Conjecture for L2L^2L2, the lower bound 2/32/\sqrt32/3​ may be achievable.

Maybe by Jung’s theorem, for L2L^2L2 distance in R2\R^2R2, any set of points with diameter at most 111 is contained in a ball of radius at most 1/31/\sqrt31/3​. This could be useful in closing the gap for L2L^2L2.

On Graphs

Does PROP clustering always exist for all graphs when N=M\mathcal N=\mathcal MN=M is the set of all nodes of the graph?

Computational Hardness

What is the computational hardness for other distance metrics?

Other ML Models

Can we adapt this PROP to other machine learning settings such as regression or classification?

Some Personal Unremarkable Rants

This paper revisit Greedy Capture. But remember M=\mathcal M=M= whole metric space, this gives different bounds.

Some dazzling new concepts like “Apollonius radius”, “shatter” etc.

Impressive spectacular showmanship on hardness proof.
entry.summary: Read the paper

entry.title: Fair AI/ML 2 PROP Fair Clustering
entry.content:
Read the paper Proportionally Fair Clustering by Chen et al.

Abstract

nnn points, kkk centers.

Proportionality: any n/kn/kn/k points are entitled to form own cluster if there is another center that is closer in distance for all n/kn/kn/k points.

Clustering with no justified complaints from any subset of agents.

Tradeoff between proportional solutions and kkk-means objective.

Introduction

In centroid clustering, we want to partition data into kkk clusters by choosing kkk centers and then matching points to one of the centers.

Each data point represents a individual. We with the clustering to be fair. These agents prefer to be clustered accurately.

A clustering is fair if it respects the entitlements of groups of agents: a subset of agents is entitled to choose a center for themselves if they constitute a sufficiently large fraction of the population w.r.t. the total number of clusters. No priori knowledge about which points should be protected.

Preliminaries

N\mathcal NN data points, ∣N∣=n|\mathcal N|=n∣N∣=n.

M\mathcal MM feasible cluster centers, ∣M∣=m|\mathcal M|=m∣M∣=m.

For i,j∈M∪Ni,j\in\mathcal M\cup\mathcal Ni,j∈M∪N, we have distance (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) satisfying the triangle inequality.

Open a set X⊆MX\subseteq\mathcal MX⊆M of ∣X∣=k|X|=k∣X∣=k centers, and then match all points in N\mathcal NN to the closest center in XXX.

For a particular solution XXX and agent i∈Ni\in\mathcal Ni∈N, let Di(X)=min⁡x∈Xd(i,x)D_i(X)=\min_{x\in X}d(i,x)Di​(X)=minx∈X​d(i,x). A good clustering solution XXX will have small values of Di(X)D_i(X)Di​(X).

Different measures, different objectives:

  • kkk-median: ∑i∈NDi(X)\sum_{i\in\mathcal N}D_i(X)∑i∈N​Di​(X)
  • kkk-means: ∑i∈N(Di(X))2\sum_{i\in\mathcal N}(D_i(X))^2∑i∈N​(Di​(X))2
  • kkk-center: max⁡i∈NDi(X)\max_{i\in\mathcal N}D_i(X)maxi∈N​Di​(X)

Individuals prefer to be closer to their center in terms of distance.

📖Definition 1. Let X⊆MX\subseteq\mathcal MX⊆M with ∣X∣=k|X|=k∣X∣=k. S⊆NS\subseteq NS⊆N is a blocking coalition against XXX if ∣S∣≥⌈nk⌉|S|\ge\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil∣S∣≥⌈kn​⌉ and ∃y∈M\exist y\in\mathcal M∃y∈M s.t. ∀i∈S,d(i,y)<Di(X)\forall i\in S,d(i,y)\lt D_i(X)∀i∈S,d(i,y)<Di​(X). X⊆NX\subseteq \mathcal NX⊆N is proportional if there is no blocking coalition against XXX.

阻塞联盟：存在一个候选中心点 yyy，存在一组数据点 SSS 满足其点数要比簇平均点数多：使得 SSS 中任意一点到 yyy 的距离，都比这组数据点到原来分配的对应簇中心点的距离近。

比例公平：一组簇分配中不包含阻塞联盟，则该簇分配是比例公平的。

Equivalently, XXX is proportional if ∀S⊆N\forall S \subseteq N∀S⊆N with ∣S∣≥⌈nk⌉|S| \ge\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil∣S∣≥⌈kn​⌉ and for all y∈My \in My∈M, there exists i∈Si \in Si∈S with d(i,y)≥Di(X)d(i, y) \ge D_i(X)d(i,y)≥Di​(X).

❗The quantification is over all subset of sufficient size. Do not consider a single i∈Si\in Si∈S and ignore all of the other points.

Advantages of PROP

  • PROP implies weak Pareto optimality: For any PROP solution XXX, there does not exist another solution X′X'X′ s.t. Di(X′)<Di(X)D_i(X')\lt D_i(X)Di​(X′)<Di​(X) for all i∈Ni\in\mathcal Ni∈N.
  • Oblivious, does not depend on sensitive attribute or protected sub-groups.
  • Robust to outlier.
  • Scale invariant: a multiplicative scaling of all distances does not affect the set of PROP solution.
  • Approximately PROP can be efficiently computed.
  • Can be efficiently checked: no need to compute entire pairwise distance matrix.

However, PROP is incompatible with kkk-center, kkk-means, kkk-median in the worst case.

📖Definition 2. X⊆MX\subseteq\mathcal MX⊆M with ∣X∣=k|X|=k∣X∣=k is ρ\rhoρ-approximate proportional (abbr. ρ\rhoρ-proportional) if ∀S⊆N\forall S\subseteq\mathcal N∀S⊆N with ∣S∣>⌈nk⌉|S|\gt\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil∣S∣>⌈kn​⌉ and ∀y∈M\forall y\in\mathcal M∀y∈M, there exists i∈Si\in Si∈S with ρ⋅d(i,y)≥Di(X)\rho\cdot d(i,y)\ge D_i(X)ρ⋅d(i,y)≥Di​(X).

Results and Outline

Existence of PROP and its approximation

PROP clustering solution doesn’t always exist.

  • Better than 222-PROP solution doesn’t always exist.

A greedy algorithm yields (1+2)(1+\sqrt2)(1+2​)-PROP solution in the worst case.

PROP as constraint

To optimize kkk-median objective subject to PROP constraint.

Use the rounding to find an O(1)O(1)O(1)-PROP solution to the kkk-median.

PROP and Randomness

PROP is approximately preserved if we take a random sample of the data points of size O~(k3)\tilde{O}(k^3)O~(k3).

For constant kkk, we can check if a given clustering s proportional as well as compute approximately PROP solutions in near linear time, comparable to the time for classic kkk-means heuristic.

Computing 2.414-PROP Clustering

Let B(x,δ)={i∈N:d(i,x)≤δ}B(x,\delta)=\{i\in\mathcal N:d(i,x)\le\delta\}B(x,δ)={i∈N:d(i,x)≤δ} (The ball of distance δ\deltaδ about center xxx).

Pseudo Code - Greedy Capture

  1. δ←0,X←∅,N←N\delta\gets0,X\gets\empty,N\gets\mathcal Nδ←0,X←∅,N←N
  2. while N≠∅N\neq\emptyN=∅, do
    • Smoothly increase δ\deltaδ
    • while ∃x∈X\exist x\in X∃x∈X s.t. ∣B(x,δ)∩N∣≥1|B(x,\delta)\cap N|\ge1∣B(x,δ)∩N∣≥1 do
      • N←N╲B(x,δ)N\gets N\diagdown B(x,\delta)N←N╲B(x,δ).
    • while ∃x∈(M╲X)\exist x\in(\mathcal M\diagdown X)∃x∈(M╲X) s.t. ∣B(x,δ)∩N∣≥⌈nk⌉|B(x,\delta)\cap N|\ge\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil∣B(x,δ)∩N∣≥⌈kn​⌉ do
      • X←X∪{x}X\gets X\cup\{x\}X←X∪{x}
      • N←N╲B(x,δ)N\gets N\diagdown B(x,\delta)N←N╲B(x,δ)
  3. return XXX

Greedy Capture runs in O~(mn)\tilde O(mn)O~(mn) time.

The algorithm continuously grows. When the ball around a center has captured ⌈nk⌉\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil⌈kn​⌉ points, we open that center and disregards all of the captured points.

Difference between kkk-means and kkk-median: Balls grow around data points in kkk-median instead of centers.

🎯Theorem 1. Greedy Capture algorithm yields a (1+2)(1+\sqrt2)(1+2​)-PROP clustering, and there exists an instance for which this bound is tight.

  1. XXX uses at most kkk centers, because it only opens a center when ⌈nk⌉\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil⌈kn​⌉ unmatched points are absorbed by the sphere. This can only happen at most kkk times.
  2. Suppose for contradiction that XXX is not (1+2)(1+\sqrt 2)(1+2​)-PROP. …

Local Capture Heuristic

Local Capture heuristic produces more proportional clustering.

It takes a target value of ρ\rhoρ as a parameter, and proceeds by iteratively finding a center that violates ρ\rhoρ-fairness and swapping it for the center in the current solution that is least demanded.

Pseudo Code - LCH

Input: ρ\rhoρ

  1. Initialize XXX as a random subset of kkk centers from M\mathcal MM.
  2. repeat until no changes occur:
    1. for y∈My\in\mathcal My∈M do
      • Sy←{i∈N:ρ⋅diy<Di(X)}S_y\gets\{i\in N:\rho\cdot d_{iy}\lt D_i(X)\}Sy​←{i∈N:ρ⋅diy​<Di​(X)}
      • if ∣Sy∣≥⌈nk⌉|S_y|\ge\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil∣Sy​∣≥⌈kn​⌉ then
        • x∗←arg⁡min⁡x∈X∣{i∈N:dix=Di(X)}∣x^*\gets\arg\min_{x\in X}|\{i\in N:d_{ix}=D_i(X)\}|x∗←argminx∈X​∣{i∈N:dix​=Di​(X)}∣
        • X←(X╲{x∗})∪{y}X\gets(X\diagdown\{x^*\})\cup\{y\}X←(X╲{x∗})∪{y}
  3. return XXX

LCH runs in O~(mn2)\tilde O(mn^2)O~(mn2) time. No guarantee of convergence! aka for a given ρ\rhoρ, there may not exist a ρ\rhoρ-proportional solution.

If LCH terminate, it must return a ρ\rhoρ-PROP solution.

PROP as a Constraint

Problem with LCH and Greedy Capture: They may find a PROP clustering with poor global objective, even when exact PROP clustering with good global objectives exist.

A bad example: k=2k=2k=2, two easily defined clusters containing 40%,60%40\%,60\%40%,60% of the data points respectively. It is possible Greedy Capture only open one point in the larger cluster. It is PROP, but not optimized w.r.t. main object.

So we need to solve this problem by optimizing the kkk-median objective subject to PROP as a constraint.

Consider kkk-median and kkk-means.

🎯Theorem 2. There is a ρ\rhoρ-PROP clustering with kkk-median objective ccc. In polynomial time in mmm and nnn, we can compute a O(ρ)O(\rho)O(ρ)-PROP clustering with kkk-median objective at most 8c8c8c.

We can compute a constant approximate PROP with kkk-median objective at most eight times the minimum kkk-median objective PROP clustering.

Linear Programming

The standard linear programming relaxation of the kkk-median minimization problem. Then add a constraint to encode PROP.

B(j,γR)B(j,\gamma R)B(j,γR) is the ball with center jjj with radius γR\gamma RγR.

zijz_{ij}zij​ is the indicator variable equal to 111 if i∈Ni\in\mathcal Ni∈N is matched to j∈Mj\in\mathcal Mj∈M.

yjy_jyj​ is the indicator variable equal to 111 if j∈Xj\in Xj∈X, i.e., if we want to use the center jjj in the clustering.

  • Objective (1) is the kkk-median objective.
  • Constraint (2) requires that every point must be matched.
  • Constraint (3) ensures that every points must be matched to the only center.
  • Constraint (4) allows at most kkk centers to be opened.

The elaboration of constraint (5): it approximately encodes PROP. Let RjR_jRj​ be the minimum value s.t. ∣B(j,Rj)∣≥⌈nk⌉|B(j,R_j)|\ge\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil∣B(j,Rj​)∣≥⌈kn​⌉. aka RjR_jRj​ is the distance of the ⌈nk⌉\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil⌈kn​⌉ farthest point in N\mathcal NN from jjj.

Sampling for Linear-Time Implementations and Auditing

PROP under uniform random sampling.

Draw ∣N∣|N|∣N∣ individuals independent and identically distributed from the uniform distribution on N\mathcal NN.

This paper shows that PROP is well preserved under random sampling.

PROP Under Random Sampling

For any X⊆MX\subseteq\mathcal MX⊆M of size kkk and center y∈My\in\mathcal My∈M, define R(N,X,y)={i∈N:Di(X)>ρ⋅d(i,y)}R(\mathcal N,X,y)=\{i\in\mathcal N:D_i(X)\gt\rho\cdot d(i,y)\}R(N,X,y)={i∈N:Di​(X)>ρ⋅d(i,y)}. Note that XXX is not ρ\rhoρ-PROP w.r.t. N\mathcal NN iff there is some y∈My\in\mathcal My∈M s.t. ∣R(N,X,y)∣∣N∣≥1k\frac{|R(\mathcal N,X,y)|}{|\mathcal N|}\ge\frac{1}{k}∣N∣∣R(N,X,y)∣​≥k1​.

A random sample approximately preserves this fraction for all solution XXX and deviating centers yyy.

Proof sketch: we take a union bound over all possible solutions and deviations, and there are only k⋅Cmkk\cdot C_m^kk⋅Cmk​ such combinations.
